TEXT.English: [TAB]Sacred buildings (from the Latin sacer 'holy') are buildings that are used by religious communities for sacred, ritual or cultic acts such as church services or sacrifices. Sacred buildings are interpreted as the presence of a higher power and are therefore colloquially referred to as places of worship.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Sacred buildings (from the Latin sacer 'holy') are buildings that are used by religious communities for sacred, ritual or cultic acts such as church services or sacrifices. Sacred buildings are interpreted as the presence of a higher power and are therefore colloquially referred to as places of worship.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Sakralbauten (von lateinisch sacer ,heilig') sind Bauwerke, die für sakrale, rituelle oder kultische Handlungen wie Gottesdienste oder Opferungen durch religiöse Gemeinschaften genutzt werden. Sakralbauten werden als Anwesenheitsorte einer höheren Macht interpretiert und werden daher umgangssprachlich auch als Gotteshäuser bezeichnet.

TEXT.English: City Planning
TEXT.French: City Planning
TEXT.German: Stadtplanung
TEXT.Italian: City Planning
TEXT.Spanish: City Planning

TEXT.English: "A city is not an accident but the result of coherent visions and aims." - Leon Krier
TEXT.French: "A city is not an accident but the result of coherent visions and aims." - Leon Krier
TEXT.German: "A city is not an accident but the result of coherent visions and aims." - Leon Krier
TEXT.Italian: "A city is not an accident but the result of coherent visions and aims." - Leon Krier
TEXT.Spanish: "A city is not an accident but the result of coherent visions and aims." - Leon Krier

TEXT.English: [TAB]Urban planning deals with the development and realization of desirable future states of a city and its sub-areas that correspond to human needs. She develops spatial concepts and processes, taking particular account of economic, ecological, social, design and technical aspects. As a rule, it is institutionalized by the state and regulates land use in the municipal area in a binding manner. This includes both public and private construction activity as well as spatial infrastructure development, ideally taking into account all public and private interests with the aim of minimizing conflict.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Urban planning deals with the development and realization of desirable future states of a city and its sub-areas that correspond to human needs. She develops spatial concepts and processes, taking particular account of economic, ecological, social, design and technical aspects. As a rule, it is institutionalized by the state and regulates land use in the municipal area in a binding manner. This includes both public and private construction activity as well as spatial infrastructure development, ideally taking into account all public and private interests with the aim of minimizing conflict.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Stadtplanung beschäftigt sich mit der Erarbeitung und Realisierung von wünschenswerten, den menschlichen Bedürfnissen entsprechenden zukünftigen Zuständen einer Stadt und ihrer Teilbereiche. Sie erarbeitet räumliche Konzepte und Prozesse und berücksichtigt dabei insbesondere ökonomische, ökologische, soziale, gestalterische und technische Gesichtspunkte. In der Regel ist sie staatlich institutionalisiert und ordnet verbindlich die Bodennutzung im Gemeindegebiet. Dies umfasst sowohl die öffentliche und die private Bautätigkeit als auch die raumbezogene Infrastrukturentwicklung, im Idealfall unter Abwägung aller öffentlichen und privaten Belange mit dem Ziel der Konfliktminimierung.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Urban planning deals with the development and realization of desirable future states of a city and its sub-areas that correspond to human needs. She develops spatial concepts and processes, taking particular account of economic, ecological, social, design and technical aspects. As a rule, it is institutionalized by the state and regulates land use in the municipal area in a binding manner. This includes both public and private construction activity as well as spatial infrastructure development, ideally taking into account all public and private interests with the aim of minimizing conflict.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Urban planning deals with the development and realization of desirable future states of a city and its sub-areas that correspond to human needs. She develops spatial concepts and processes, taking particular account of economic, ecological, social, design and technical aspects. This includes both public and private construction activity as well as spatial infrastructure development, ideally taking into account all public and private interests with the aim of minimizing conflict.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The engineering discipline dealing with the design, construction and repair of marine vehicles, naval architecture involves research, design, development and calculation in all stages of the life of a marine vehicle. Traditionally, naval architecture has been more craft than science, the shape of a vessel being judged by the use of scale models or prototypes. In Europe, Viking longships were developed from the use of "clinker" or overlapped planking though later European vessels favoured more rounded hulls with a broad beam and heavily curved at both ends. Later innovations included a straight steerpost enabling the mounting of a moveable rudder and a mixed array of both lateen and square-rigged sails on ocean-going vessels.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The engineering discipline dealing with the design, construction and repair of marine vehicles, naval architecture involves research, design, development and calculation in all stages of the life of a marine vehicle. Traditionally, naval architecture has been more craft than science, the shape of a vessel being judged by the use of scale models or prototypes. In Europe, Viking longships were developed from the use of "clinker" or overlapped planking though later European vessels favoured more rounded hulls with a broad beam and heavily curved at both ends. Later innovations included a straight steerpost enabling the mounting of a moveable rudder and a mixed array of both lateen and square-rigged sails on ocean-going vessels.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Ingenieurdisziplin, die sich mit der Konstruktion, dem Bau und der Reparatur von Schiffsfahrzeugen befasst, umfasst Forschung, Design, Entwicklung und Berechnung in allen Phasen der Lebensdauer eines Schiffsfahrzeugs. Traditionell war der Schiffsbau eher ein Handwerk als eine Wissenschaft, wobei die Form eines Schiffes anhand maßstabsgetreuer Modelle oder Prototypen beurteilt wurde. In Europa wurden Wikinger-Langschiffe aus "Klinker" oder überlappenden Beplankungen entwickelt, obwohl spätere europäische Schiffe eher abgerundete Rümpfe mit breiter Breite und stark gebogenen Rümpfen an beiden Enden bevorzugten. Zu den späteren Innovationen gehörten ein gerader Steuerpfosten, der die Montage eines beweglichen Ruders und eine gemischte Anordnung von Lateiner- und Rahsegeln auf Hochseeschiffen ermöglichte.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]The engineering discipline dealing with the design, construction and repair of marine vehicles, naval architecture involves research, design, development and calculation in all stages of the life of a marine vehicle. Traditionally, naval architecture has been more craft than science, the shape of a vessel being judged by the use of scale models or prototypes. In Europe, Viking longships were developed from the use of "clinker" or overlapped planking though later European vessels favoured more rounded hulls with a broad beam and heavily curved at both ends. Later innovations included a straight steerpost enabling the mounting of a moveable rudder and a mixed array of both lateen and square-rigged sails on ocean-going vessels.

TEXT.English: Patronage
TEXT.French: Patronage
TEXT.German: Patronage
TEXT.Italian: Patronage
TEXT.Spanish: Patronage

TEXT.English: [TAB]Patronage is the support, encouragement, privilege and financial aid that an organization or individual bestows on another. In the history of art, patronage refers to the support kings, popes or the wealthy provided to musicians, painters and sculptors, acting as sponsors of individual artists to enhance their prestige, political ambitions or social position. Some patrons like the Medici family of Florence and the Papacy supported the the creation of religious art and architecture by their commissioning of churches, cathedrals, paintings and sculpture. Artists and writers such as Michelangelo, Raphael, Da Vinci, Shakespeare and Ben Jonson all enjoyed the direct support of wealthy noble or ecclesiastical patrons.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Patronage is the support, encouragement, privilege and financial aid that an organization or individual bestows on another. In the history of art, patronage refers to the support kings, popes or the wealthy provided to musicians, painters and sculptors, acting as sponsors of individual artists to enhance their prestige, political ambitions or social position. Some patrons like the Medici family of Florence and the Papacy supported the the creation of religious art and architecture by their commissioning of churches, cathedrals, paintings and sculpture. Artists and writers such as Michelangelo, Raphael, Da Vinci, Shakespeare and Ben Jonson all enjoyed the direct support of wealthy noble or ecclesiastical patrons.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der Begriff Kunstpatronage bezeichnet das Auftragsverhältnis zwischen einem Künstler und seinem Auftraggeber, bei dem der Patron die finanziellen und sozialen Voraussetzungen zur Umsetzung des Kunstwerkes schafft. Für gewöhnlich wird die Bezeichnung Kunstpatronage für die Kunstförderung des späten Mittelalters und der Frühen Neuzeit verwendet.[PARAGRAPH:2]Als Auftraggeber traten meist wohlhabende Prälaten, Fürsten, Kaufleute oder Privatpersonen, aber auch Personengruppen wie Ordensgemeinschaften, Gremien, Zünften oder Bruderschaften auf. Die Kunstpatronage fand auf dem Gebiet der bildenden und der angewandten Kunst statt. Malerei und Bildhauerei, Architektur und Kunsthandwerk sowie Musik, Theater und Literatur wurden durch dieses System gefördert und in gewisser Weise auch gesteuert. Eine enge Beziehung zwischen Künstler und Auftraggeber auf persönlicher Ebene war bei einer kontinuierlichen, langjährigen Kunstpatronage nicht ungewöhnlich.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Patronage is the support, encouragement, privilege and financial aid that an organization or individual bestows on another. In the history of art, patronage refers to the support kings, popes or the wealthy provided to musicians, painters and sculptors, acting as sponsors of individual artists to enhance their prestige, political ambitions or social position. Some patrons like the Medici family of Florence and the Papacy supported the the creation of religious art and architecture by their commissioning of churches, cathedrals, paintings and sculpture. Artists and writers such as Michelangelo, Raphael, Da Vinci, Shakespeare and Ben Jonson all enjoyed the direct support of wealthy noble or ecclesiastical patrons.

TEXT.English: [TAB]An asymmetrical war is a military conflict between parties that are very different in terms of weapons technology, organization and strategy. Because asymmetric warfare differs from the usual image of war, the term asymmetric conflict is also used.
TEXT.French: [TAB]An asymmetrical war is a military conflict between parties that are very different in terms of weapons technology, organization and strategy. Because asymmetric warfare differs from the usual image of war, the term asymmetric conflict is also used.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ein asymmetrischer Krieg ist eine militärische Auseinandersetzung zwischen Parteien, die waffentechnisch, organisatorisch und strategisch stark unterschiedlich ausgerichtet sind. Weil sich die asymmetrische Kriegführung vom gewohnten Bild des Krieges unterscheidet, wird auch die Bezeichnung asymmetrischer Konflikt verwendet.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]An asymmetrical war is a military conflict between parties that are very different in terms of weapons technology, organization and strategy. Because asymmetric warfare differs from the usual image of war, the term asymmetric conflict is also used.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]An asymmetrical war is a military conflict between parties that are very different in terms of weapons technology, organization and strategy. Because asymmetric warfare differs from the usual image of war, the term asymmetric conflict is also used.

TEXT.English: Mechanical Engineering
TEXT.French: Mechanical Engineering
TEXT.German: Maschinenbau
TEXT.Italian: Mechanical Engineering
TEXT.Spanish: Mechanical Engineering

TEXT.English: [TAB]Engineering is the application of scientific and mathematical principles to the design and/or manufacture of theoretical systems and physical objects. Prior to the mid-18th century, military engineers carried out all engineering functions. Their work involved the construction of roads, bridges, fortifications, and the performance of other duties relating to the military. In the late 18th century, civil engineers took over all non-military engineering functions. Other fields of engineering prior to the 20th century included mining engineers, who designed mines and methods of mining, and mechanical engineers, who dealt with the design and construction of machinery. As new technologies developed, new fields of engineering developed along with them. Today, there are engineers specifically trained in nearly every field, from electronics and computers to chemistry and atomics.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Engineering is the application of scientific and mathematical principles to the design and/or manufacture of theoretical systems and physical objects. Prior to the mid-18th century, military engineers carried out all engineering functions. Their work involved the construction of roads, bridges, fortifications, and the performance of other duties relating to the military. In the late 18th century, civil engineers took over all non-military engineering functions. Other fields of engineering prior to the 20th century included mining engineers, who designed mines and methods of mining, and mechanical engineers, who dealt with the design and construction of machinery. As new technologies developed, new fields of engineering developed along with them. Today, there are engineers specifically trained in nearly every field, from electronics and computers to chemistry and atomics.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Als Maschinenbau versteht man die Anwendung von wissenschaftlichen und mathematischen Prinzipien zum Entwurf und/oder zur Herstellung von theoretischen Systemen und physikalischen Objekten. Ab etwa Mitte des 18. Jahrhunderts wurden alle das Ingenieurwesen betreffenden Aufgaben von Militäringenieuren ausgeführt. Ihr Betätigungsfeld schloss den Bau von Straßen, Brücken, Befestigungen sowie andere Aufgaben ein, die mit dem Militär zu tun hatten. Im späten 18. Jahrhundert übernahmen dann Zivilingenieure alle nicht militärischen Aufgaben. Zu den weiteren Fachingenieuren gehörten in der Zeit vor dem 20. Jahrhundert die Bergbauingenieure, die Bergwerke und Bergbaumethoden konzipierten, sowie die Maschinenbauingenieure, in deren Aufgabenbereich der Entwurf und die Konstruktion von Maschinen fiel. Mit der Entwicklung neuer Technologien stieg auch die Anzahl der Fachbereiche im Ingenieurwesen. Heute werden die Ingenieure speziell für ihr Fachgebiet ausgebildet, angefangen bei der Elektronik und der Computertechnologie bis hin zur Chemie und der Atomwissenschaft.

Prior to the mid-18th century, military engineers carried out all engineering functions. Their work involved the construction of roads, bridges, fortifications, and the performance of other duties relating to the military. In the late 18th century, civil engineers took over all non-military engineering functions. Other fields of engineering prior to the 20th century included mining engineers, who designed mines and methods of mining, and mechanical engineers, who dealt with the design and construction of machinery. As new technologies developed, new fields of engineering developed along with them. Today, there are engineers specifically trained in nearly every field, from electronics and computers to chemistry and atomics.

TEXT.English: Cartography
TEXT.French: Cartography
TEXT.German: Kartographie
TEXT.Italian: Cartography
TEXT.Spanish: Cartography

TEXT.English: [TAB]Cartography, or map making, is the practice of making geographical maps which developed in ancient Greece and Rome in the 6thC. BC. An early example was Ptolemy's map of the known world in the 2ndC. AD. Arab geographers began to translate the works of Greek geographers into Arabic and many "mappa mundi" were produced in early medieval Europe, but the first accurate atlas of maps was produced by the Arab geographer al-Idrisi in 1154, incorporating knowledge of Europe, Africa, the Indian Ocean and the Far East. Later European geographers relied heavily on previous maps and the observations of explorers but were aided by the introduction of the magnetic compass, telescope and sextant which improved the accuracy of map making greatly.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Cartography, or map making, is the practice of making geographical maps which developed in ancient Greece and Rome in the 6thC. BC. An early example was Ptolemy's map of the known world in the 2ndC. AD. Arab geographers began to translate the works of Greek geographers into Arabic and many "mappa mundi" were produced in early medieval Europe, but the first accurate atlas of maps was produced by the Arab geographer al-Idrisi in 1154, incorporating knowledge of Europe, Africa, the Indian Ocean and the Far East. Later European geographers relied heavily on previous maps and the observations of explorers but were aided by the introduction of the magnetic compass, telescope and sextant which improved the accuracy of map making greatly.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Kartografie (auch Kartographie) ist die Wissenschaft und Technik zur Darstellung der Erdoberfläche in topografischen und thematischen Karten, im einfachsten Fall Landkarten.[PARAGRAPH:2]Die ältesten Karten stammen bereits aus dem Neolithikum. Eine Wandmalerei zeigt eine zentralanatolische Siedlung um 6200 v. Chr. mit ihren Häusern und dem Doppelgipfel des Vulkans Hasan Dagi (3.270 m). Bedeutende frühe Zeugnisse stammen aus der babylonischen Zeit (geritzte Tontafeln). Den ersten ernsthaften Versuch eine brauchbare Karte unter mathematischen und geometrischen Aspekten anzufertigen unternahm Anaximander von Milet (ein Schüler des Thales) um 541 v. Chr.[PARAGRAPH:2]Im Mittelalter entstanden die ersten Kartenwerke von muslimischen Geographen, die auf der Grundlage neuerer Beobachtungen, Messungen und Entdeckungen das im 8. Jahrhundert ins Arabische übersetzte Werk des Ptolemäus korrigierten und erheblichen Einfluss auf die europäische Kartografie ausübten. Hervorzuheben sind hier al-Istakhris Karten aus dem 10. Jahrhundert, und die im Auftrag König Rogers II. von Sizilien 1154 angefertigte Weltkarte Charta Rogeriana von Abu Abdallah al-Idrisi (auch Weltkarte des Idrisi genannt).[PARAGRAPH:2]Im späten Mittelalter entstanden die mappae mundi mit ihren bekanntesten Vertretern, der Ebstorfer Weltkarte (ca. 1235) und der Hereforder Weltkarte (ca. 1270). Parallel gab es bereits recht genaue Karten des Mittelmeeres, die sog. Portolankarten. Das Bild am Ende des Mittelalters zeigt der Globus des Nürnberger Gelehrten Martin Behaim von 1492.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Cartography, or map making, is the practice of making geographical maps which developed in ancient Greece and Rome in the 6thC. BC. An early example was Ptolemy's map of the known world in the 2ndC. AD. Arab geographers began to translate the works of Greek geographers into Arabic and many "mappa mundi" were produced in early medieval Europe, but the first accurate atlas of maps was produced by the Arab geographer al-Idrisi in 1154, incorporating knowledge of Europe, Africa, the Indian Ocean and the Far East. Later European geographers relied heavily on previous maps and the observations of explorers but were aided by the introduction of the magnetic compass, telescope and sextant which improved the accuracy of map making greatly.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Imperialism is the practice, theory or attitude of maintaining or extending power over foreign nations, particularly through expansionism, employing not only hard power (economic and military power), but also soft power (cultural and diplomatic power). Imperialism focuses on establishing or maintaining hegemony and a more or less formal empire.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Imperialism is the practice, theory or attitude of maintaining or extending power over foreign nations, particularly through expansionism, employing not only hard power (economic and military power), but also soft power (cultural and diplomatic power). Imperialism focuses on establishing or maintaining hegemony and a more or less formal empire.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Imperialismus ist die Praxis, Theorie oder Haltung der Aufrechterhaltung oder Ausweitung der Macht über fremde Nationen, insbesondere durch Expansionismus, wobei nicht nur harte Macht (wirtschaftliche und militärische Macht), sondern auch weiche Macht (kulturelle und diplomatische Macht) eingesetzt wird. Der Schwerpunkt des Imperialismus liegt auf der Errichtung oder Aufrechterhaltung einer Hegemonie und eines mehr oder weniger formellen Imperiums.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Imperialism is the practice, theory or attitude of maintaining or extending power over foreign nations, particularly through expansionism, employing not only hard power (economic and military power), but also soft power (cultural and diplomatic power). Imperialism focuses on establishing or maintaining hegemony and a more or less formal empire.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Economy is the totality of all institutions and actions that serve the planned satisfaction of needs. Economic institutions include companies, private and public households, and economic activities include the manufacture, sale, exchange, consumption, circulation, distribution and recycling/disposal of goods. Such connections exist, for example, at the world, national, city, business and household level.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Economy is the totality of all institutions and actions that serve the planned satisfaction of needs. Economic institutions include companies, private and public households, and economic activities include the manufacture, sale, exchange, consumption, circulation, distribution and recycling/disposal of goods. Such connections exist, for example, at the world, national, city, business and household level.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Wirtschaft oder Ökonomie ist die Gesamtheit aller Einrichtungen und Handlungen, die der planvollen Befriedigung der Bedürfnisse dienen. Zu den wirtschaftlichen Einrichtungen gehören Unternehmen, private und öffentliche Haushalte, zu den Handlungen des Wirtschaftens Herstellung, Absatz, Tausch, Konsum, Umlauf, Verteilung und Recycling/Entsorgung von Gütern. Solche Zusammenhänge bestehen zum Beispiel auf welt-, volks-, stadt-, betriebs- und hauswirtschaftlicher Ebene.

Economic institutions include companies, private and public households, and economic activities include the manufacture, sale, exchange, consumption, circulation, distribution and recycling/disposal of goods. Such connections exist, for example, at the world, national, city, business and household level.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The first major written Arabic work was the Qur'an, the holy book of the Islamic faith. With the spread of Islam, Arabic became the written language of the conquered lands, and Arabic became a major world language. During and after this period, people of many different ethnic origins used Arabic as their literary language. The first major literature to be written in this language was in the form of poetry, specifically qasidas, epic poems originally performed orally and akin to sagas of the Norse lands. These began to be written down during the Umayyad dynasty (661-750 AD). With the rise of the Abbasid dynasty (750-1258), the qasidas were joined by general writings known as adab, a word that now means literature, but then meant refinement. Adab referred to prose writing that educated and refined readers by providing information about the world around them and included essays and book-length works on such topics as language and style, the history of other peoples and nations, scientific subjects, intellectual and philosophical questions and human nature. While the Dark Ages held Europe in its grip of fear, superstition and ignorance, the lands of the Muslim World continued on, having translated the most important works of Western science, and added to this stockpile their continuing pursuit of knowledge. These Arabic texts, some from Cordovan Spain, but many more from plunder during the Crusades, allowed Europe to regain many secrets that they had previously lost.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The first major written Arabic work was the Qur'an, the holy book of the Islamic faith. With the spread of Islam, Arabic became the written language of the conquered lands, and Arabic became a major world language. During and after this period, people of many different ethnic origins used Arabic as their literary language. The first major literature to be written in this language was in the form of poetry, specifically qasidas, epic poems originally performed orally and akin to sagas of the Norse lands. Adab referred to prose writing that educated and refined readers by providing information about the world around them and included essays and book-length works on such topics as language and style, the history of other peoples and nations, scientific subjects, intellectual and philosophical questions and human nature. While the Dark Ages held Europe in its grip of fear, superstition and ignorance, the lands of the Muslim World continued on, having translated the most important works of Western science, and added to this stockpile their continuing pursuit of knowledge. These Arabic texts, some from Cordovan Spain, but many more from plunder during the Crusades, allowed Europe to regain many secrets that they had previously lost.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Das erste große schriftliche arabische Werk war der Qur'an, das heilige Buch des islamischen Glaubens. Mit der Verbreitung des Islam wurde Arabisch zur Schriftsprache der eroberten Länder und Arabisch wurde zu einer wichtigen Weltsprache. Während und nach dieser Zeit verwendeten Menschen unterschiedlichster ethnischer Herkunft Arabisch als ihre literarische Sprache. Die erste große Literatur, die in dieser Sprache verfasst wurde, bestand aus Gedichten, insbesondere Qasidas, epischen Gedichten, die ursprünglich mündlich vorgetragen wurden und den Sagen der nordischen Länder ähnelten. Diese wurden während der Umayyaden-Dynastie (661-750 n. Chr.) niedergeschrieben. Mit dem Aufstieg der Abbasiden-Dynastie (750-1258) kamen zu den Qasidas allgemeine Schriften hinzu, die als Adab bekannt sind, ein Wort, das heute Literatur, damals aber Verfeinerung bedeutete. Adab bezog sich auf das Schreiben von Prosa, das den Leser durch die Bereitstellung von Informationen über die Welt um ihn herum bildete und verfeinerte und Essays und buchlange Werke zu Themen wie Sprache und Stil, der Geschichte anderer Völker und Nationen, wissenschaftlichen Themen, intellektuellen und philosophischen Fragen usw. umfasste menschliche Natur. Während das dunkle Zeitalter Europa im Griff von Angst, Aberglauben und Unwissenheit hielt, machten die Länder der muslimischen Welt weiter, indem sie die wichtigsten Werke der westlichen Wissenschaft übersetzten und diesen Vorrat durch ihr kontinuierliches Streben nach Wissen ergänzten. Diese arabischen Texte, von denen einige aus Cordoba-Spanien stammen, viele andere jedoch aus Plünderungen während der Kreuzzüge stammen, ermöglichten es Europa, viele Geheimnisse zurückzugewinnen, die es zuvor verloren hatte.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The smelting of iron in bloomeries probably began in Anatolia or the Caucasus in the second millennium BC or the latter part of the preceding one. Cast iron was first produced in China about 550 BC, but not in Europe until early in the second millennium AD. During the medieval period, means were found in Europe of producing wrought iron from cast iron (in this context known as pig iron) using finery forges. For all these processes, charcoal was required as fuel.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The smelting of iron in bloomeries probably began in Anatolia or the Caucasus in the second millennium BC or the latter part of the preceding one. Cast iron was first produced in China about 550 BC, but not in Europe until early in the second millennium AD. During the medieval period, means were found in Europe of producing wrought iron from cast iron (in this context known as pig iron) using finery forges. For all these processes, charcoal was required as fuel.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Das Schmelzen von Eisen in Blumentöpfen begann wahrscheinlich in Anatolien oder im Kaukasus im zweiten Jahrtausend v. Chr. oder in der zweiten Hälfte des vorangegangenen Jahrtausends. Gusseisen wurde erstmals etwa 550 v. Chr. in China hergestellt, in Europa jedoch erst Anfang des zweiten Jahrtausends n. Chr. Im Mittelalter wurden in Europa Möglichkeiten gefunden, mithilfe von Putzschmieden aus Gusseisen (in diesem Zusammenhang als Roheisen bezeichnet) Schmiedeeisen herzustellen. Für alle diese Prozesse wurde Holzkohle als Brennstoff benötigt.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The term proselytism originally referred to the turning of other peoples to Judaism. Today, in religion or mission, it is a negative term for the poaching of believers from other denominations, churches and faith communities who are to be persuaded to enter their own denomination or church community.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The term proselytism originally referred to the turning of other peoples to Judaism. Today, in religion or mission, it is a negative term for the poaching of believers from other denominations, churches and faith communities who are to be persuaded to enter their own denomination or church community.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der Ausdruck Proselytismus bezeichnete ursprünglich die Hinwendung anderer Völker zum Judentum. In heutiger Zeit ist es in der Religion bzw. Mission eine negative Bezeichnung für das Abwerben von Gläubigen aus anderen Konfessionen, Kirchen und Glaubensgemeinschaften, die zum Eintritt in die eigene Konfession oder kirchliche Gemeinschaft bewegt werden sollen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]The term proselytism originally referred to the turning of other peoples to Judaism. TEXT.English: [TAB]Agriculture is the science of cultivating soil, planting and harvesting crops. It can be argued that the mastery of agriculture was the single most important step towards creating a civilization, as agriculture allowed people to stop hunting and gathering and settle down in one place. Villages and cities would be unviable without some form of agriculture. [PARAGRAPH:2]Evidence of plant cultivation dates back as far as 6000 BC. Apparently, grains were some of the earliest crops cultivated. Grains are incredibly useful foodstuffs; they can be ground into flour and turned into bread, they can be fed to livestock and, perhaps most importantly, they can be stored for months without spoiling. [PARAGRAPH:2]Over time a number of important tools were invented to aid in cultivation and preparation of grains. The sickle was an early innovation; it allowed the grain to be harvested far quicker than by hand. Hand mills and mortar and pestles were created to grind the finished product, and pots to store it. As man learned about fertilization and irrigation, it became possible to get consistently larger yields, which lessoned the chances of famine and increased the numbers that could be fed from each field.

The sickle was an early innovation; it allowed the grain to be harvested far quicker than by hand. Hand mills and mortar and pestles were created to grind the finished product, and pots to store it. As man learned about fertilization and irrigation, it became possible to get consistently larger yields, which lessoned the chances of famine and increased the numbers that could be fed from each field.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Unter dem Begriff "Landwirtschaft" wird die Kultivierung der Erde, das Ausbringen der Saat und die Ernte der Feldfrüchte zusammengefasst. Die Entwicklung der Landwirtschaft war zweifelsfrei eine wichtige Grundlage für die Entstehung der Zivilisation, da Dörfer und Städte ohne eine wie auch immer geartete Landwirtschaft nicht denkbar gewesen wären. [PARAGRAPH:2]Der Anbau von Kulturpflanzen nahm mit verschiedenen Getreidearten bereits um 6000 vor Christus seinen Anfang. Getreide war ein außerordentlich vielseitiges Nahrungsmittel, das zu Mehl verarbeitet oder an das Vieh verfüttert werden konnte. Darüber hinaus konnte es monatelang gelagert werden, ohne zu verderben. [PARAGRAPH:2]Im Laufe der Zeit entstanden verschiedene Werkzeuge für den Anbau und die Verarbeitung des Getreides. Während die Sichel die Ernte des reifen Getreides erleichterte, verwendete man Mühlen, Mörser und Stößel, um das Getreide zu mahlen und anschließend in Töpfen zu lagern. Später ermöglichten Düngemittel und Bewässerungssysteme größere Ernten und verringerten so die Gefahr von Hungersnöten.

[PARAGRAPH:2]Over time a number of important tools were invented to aid in cultivation and preparation of grains. The sickle was an early innovation; it allowed the grain to be harvested far quicker than by hand. Hand mills and mortar and pestles were created to grind the finished product, and pots to store it. As man learned about fertilization and irrigation, it became possible to get consistently larger yields, which lessoned the chances of famine and increased the numbers that could be fed from each field.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A welfare state is a concept of government where the state plays a key role in the protection and promotion of the economic and social well-being of its citizens. The Islamic Caliphate has been described as the world's first major welfare state, largely due to the Islamic concepts of Zakat and Khums. Zakat is a form of mandatory charity. Once a year, any able Muslim is obligied to give away some amount (usually 2.5 percent) of his wealth to the poor. Khums is the tradition of giving one-fifth of one's wealth to the Islamic cause, e.g. to fund the building of a mosque. In Sunni view, this only applies to spoils of war, whereas Shias believe that it also applies to monetary profit in general.
TEXT.French: [TAB]A welfare state is a concept of government where the state plays a key role in the protection and promotion of the economic and social well-being of its citizens. The Islamic Caliphate has been described as the world's first major welfare state, largely due to the Islamic concepts of Zakat and Khums. Zakat is a form of mandatory charity. Once a year, any able Muslim is obligied to give away some amount (usually 2.5 percent) of his wealth to the poor. Khums is the tradition of giving one-fifth of one's wealth to the Islamic cause, e.g. to fund the building of a mosque. In Sunni view, this only applies to spoils of war, whereas Shias believe that it also applies to monetary profit in general.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ein Wohlfahrtsstaat ist ein Regierungskonzept, bei dem der Staat eine Schlüsselrolle beim Schutz und der Förderung des wirtschaftlichen und sozialen Wohlergehens seiner Bürger spielt. Das islamische Kalifat wurde als der erste große Wohlfahrtsstaat der Welt beschrieben, was vor allem auf die islamischen Konzepte von Zakat und Khums zurückzuführen ist. Zakat ist eine Form der obligatorischen Wohltätigkeit. Einmal im Jahr ist jeder fähige Muslim verpflichtet, einen Teil (normalerweise 2,5 Prozent) seines Vermögens an die Armen zu spenden. Khums ist die Tradition, ein Fünftel seines Vermögens für die islamische Sache zu spenden, z.B. um den Bau einer Moschee zu finanzieren. Aus sunnitischer Sicht gilt dies nur für Kriegsbeute, während Schiiten davon ausgehen, dass dies auch für Geldgewinne im Allgemeinen gilt.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Manorialism is the organization of rural economy and society in medieval western and parts of central Europe, characterised by the vesting of legal and economic power in a lord supported economically from his own direct landholding and from the obligatory contributions of a legally subject part of the peasant population under his jurisdiction. These obligations could be payable in labour, produce ("in kind") or rarely money. [PARAGRAPH:2]The word derives from traditional inherited divisions of the countryside reassigned as local jurisdictions known as manors; each manor being subject to a lord, usually holding his position in return for undertakings offered to a higher lord. The lord held a manor court governed by public law and local custom. Not all territorial manors were secular: bishops and abbots held lands that entailed similar obligations.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Manorialism is the organization of rural economy and society in medieval western and parts of central Europe, characterised by the vesting of legal and economic power in a lord supported economically from his own direct landholding and from the obligatory contributions of a legally subject part of the peasant population under his jurisdiction. These obligations could be payable in labour, produce ("in kind") or rarely money. [PARAGRAPH:2]The word derives from traditional inherited divisions of the countryside reassigned as local jurisdictions known as manors; each manor being subject to a lord, usually holding his position in return for undertakings offered to a higher lord. The lord held a manor court governed by public law and local custom. Not all territorial manors were secular: bishops and abbots held lands that entailed similar obligations.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Manorialismus ist die Organisation der ländlichen Wirtschaft und Gesellschaft im mittelalterlichen West- und Teilen Mitteleuropas, gekennzeichnet durch die Übertragung rechtlicher und wirtschaftlicher Macht an einen Herrn, der sich wirtschaftlich aus seinem eigenen direkten Landbesitz und aus den Pflichtbeiträgen eines rechtlich unterworfenen Teils ernährt der seiner Gerichtsbarkeit unterstehenden bäuerlichen Bevölkerung. Diese Verpflichtungen können in Form von Arbeit, Erzeugnissen ("in Form von Sachleistungen") oder in seltenen Fällen auch in Geld zahlbar sein. [PARAGRAPH:2]Das Wort leitet sich von traditionellen geerbten Landteilen ab, die als lokale Gerichtsbarkeiten, sogenannte Herrenhäuser, neu zugewiesen wurden; Jedes Herrenhaus war einem Herrn untertan, der seine Position normalerweise im Gegenzug für Verpflichtungen behielt, die einem höheren Herrn angeboten wurden. Der Gutsherr verfügte über ein Gutsgericht, das dem öffentlichen Recht und den örtlichen Gepflogenheiten unterlag. Nicht alle Landgüter waren weltlich: Bischöfe und Äbte besaßen Ländereien, die mit ähnlichen Verpflichtungen verbunden waren.

These obligations could be payable in labour, produce ("in kind") or rarely money. [PARAGRAPH:2]The word derives from traditional inherited divisions of the countryside reassigned as local jurisdictions known as manors; each manor being subject to a lord, usually holding his position in return for undertakings offered to a higher lord. The lord held a manor court governed by public law and local custom. Not all territorial manors were secular: bishops and abbots held lands that entailed similar obligations.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The original ploughs were light and fragile, but around 7th century AD the runner was replaced by wheels, which enabled greater size and weight of the plough, and subsequently contribitued to increased food output and population growth in Europe and the Middle East.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The original ploughs were light and fragile, but around 7th century AD the runner was replaced by wheels, which enabled greater size and weight of the plough, and subsequently contribitued to increased food output and population growth in Europe and the Middle East.

Chr. wurde die Kufe durch Räder ersetzt, was eine größere Größe und ein größeres Gewicht des Pfluges ermöglichte und in der Folge zu einer höheren Nahrungsmittelproduktion und einem Bevölkerungswachstum in Europa und dem Nahen Osten beitrug.

TEXT.English: Barter
TEXT.French: Barter
TEXT.German: Tauschhandel
TEXT.Italian: Barter
TEXT.Spanish: Barter

TEXT.English: [TAB]To organise production and to distribute goods and services among their populations, many pre-capitalist or pre-market economies relied on tradition, top-down command, or community democracy instead of market exchange organised using barter. Relations of reciprocity and/or redistribution substituted for market exchange. Trade and barter were primarily reserved for trade between communities or countries. It is also used when the monetary system failed to measure the economic value of goods.
TEXT.French: [TAB]To organise production and to distribute goods and services among their populations, many pre-capitalist or pre-market economies relied on tradition, top-down command, or community democracy instead of market exchange organised using barter. Relations of reciprocity and/or redistribution substituted for market exchange. Trade and barter were primarily reserved for trade between communities or countries. It is also used when the monetary system failed to measure the economic value of goods.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Um die Produktion zu organisieren und Güter und Dienstleistungen unter ihrer Bevölkerung zu verteilen, verließen sich viele vorkapitalistische oder vormarktwirtschaftliche Wirtschaftssysteme auf Tradition, Top-Down-Befehl oder Gemeinschaftsdemokratie statt auf einen durch Tauschhandel organisierten Marktaustausch. Reziprozitäts- und/oder Umverteilungsbeziehungen ersetzten den Marktaustausch. Handel und Tauschhandel waren in erster Linie dem Handel zwischen Gemeinschaften oder Ländern vorbehalten. Es wird auch verwendet, wenn das Währungssystem den wirtschaftlichen Wert von Gütern nicht messen konnte.

TEXT.English: [TAB]An astrolabe is a historical astronomical instrument used by astronomers, navigators, and astrologers. An early astrolabe was invented in the Hellenistic world in 150 BC and was used through the Classical Antiquity. During the Islamic Golden Age, Arab astronomers introduced angular scales to the astrolabe, adding circles indicating azimuths on the horizon. It was widely used throughout the Muslim world, chiefly as an aid to navigation and as a way of finding the Qibla, the direction of Mecca. The first person credited with building the astrolabe in the Islamic world is reportedly the 8th century mathematician, Muhammad al-Fazari. In the 10th century, al-Sufi first described over 1,000 different uses of an astrolabe, in areas as diverse as astronomy, astrology, horoscopes, navigation, surveying, timekeeping, prayer, Salah, Qibla, etc.

In the 10th century, al-Sufi first described over 1,000 different uses of an astrolabe, in areas as diverse as astronomy, astrology, horoscopes, navigation, surveying, timekeeping, prayer, Salah, Qibla, etc.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ein Astrolabium ist ein historisches astronomisches Instrument, das von Astronomen, Navigatoren und Astrologen verwendet wird. Ein frühes Astrolabium wurde 150 v. Chr. in der hellenistischen Welt erfunden und bis in die klassische Antike hinein verwendet. Während des islamischen Goldenen Zeitalters führten arabische Astronomen Winkelskalen in das Astrolabium ein und fügten Kreise hinzu, die Azimute am Horizont anzeigten. Es wurde in der gesamten muslimischen Welt häufig verwendet, hauptsächlich als Navigationshilfe und als Weg, die Qibla, die Richtung nach Mekka, zu finden. Die erste Person, der der Bau des Astrolabiums in der islamischen Welt zugeschrieben wird, ist angeblich der Mathematiker Muhammad al-Fazari aus dem 8. Jahrhundert. Im 10. Jahrhundert beschrieb al-Sufi erstmals über 1.000 verschiedene Verwendungsmöglichkeiten eines Astrolabiums in so unterschiedlichen Bereichen wie Astronomie, Astrologie, Horoskope, Navigation, Vermessung, Zeitmessung, Gebet, Salah, Qibla usw.

TEXT.English: Stirrup
TEXT.French: Stirrup
TEXT.German: Steigbügel
TEXT.Italian: Stirrup
TEXT.Spanish: Stirrup

TEXT.English: "If you speak the truth, have a foot in the stirrup." - Turkish proverb
TEXT.French: "If you speak the truth, have a foot in the stirrup." - Turkish proverb
TEXT.German: "Wer die Wahrheit spricht, sollte besser einen Fuß im Steigbügel haben." - Arabisches Sprichwort
TEXT.Italian: "If you speak the truth, have a foot in the stirrup." - Turkish proverb
TEXT.Spanish: "If you speak the truth, have a foot in the stirrup." - Turkish proverb

TEXT.English: [TAB]The stirrup is a ring with a flat bottom fixed on a leather strap, usually hung from each side of a saddle to create a footrest for the rider on a riding animal (usually a horse or other equine, such as mule), suspended by an adjustable strap from the saddle for use as a support for the foot of a rider of a horse when seated in the saddle and as an aid in mounting. It greatly increases the rider's ability to control the mount, increasing the animal's usefulness in communication, transportation and warfare. It is considered one of the basic tools used to create and spread modern civilization. Some argue it is as important as the wheel or printing press. [PARAGRAPH:2]The stirrup was invented relatively late in history, considering that horses were domesticated approximately 4,500 BC. The first dependable representation of a rider with paired stirrups was found in China in a Jin Dynasty tomb of about 322 AD. The stirrup spread throughout Eurasia by the horsemen of the central Asian steppes. The Greeks and Romans did not use them but mounted by vaulting or from a mounting block. By the 7th century, thanks primarily to invaders from Central Asia, such as the Mongols, stirrups spread across Asia to Europe. By the 8th century, they appear to have been adopted by the Europeans. Stirrups were first indirectly documented in Central Europe during the reign of Charles Martel. [PARAGRAPH:2]In the use of horses in warfare, the stirrup was the third revolutionary step in equipment, after the chariot and the saddle of the mounted horseman. Stirrups changed the basic tactics of mounted warfare and made cavalry more important. Braced against the stirrups, a knight could deliver a blow with a lance that employed the full weight and momentum of horse and rider together. Reacting to a sudden and urgent demand for cavalry, Charlemagne ordered his poorer vassals to pool their resources and provide a mounted and armed knight. The addition of stirrups also allowed a rider to use a longer (and vastly more powerful) bow by standing up on the stirrups.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Der Steigbügel ist ein Ring mit flachem Boden, der an einem Lederband befestigt ist und normalerweise an beiden Seiten eines Sattels aufgehängt wird, um dem Reiter auf einem Reittier (normalerweise einem Pferd oder einem anderen Pferd, z. B. einem Maultier) eine Fußstütze zu bieten. Mit einem verstellbaren Riemen am Sattel aufgehängt, dient es als Stütze für den Fuß eines Reiters, wenn er im Sattel sitzt, und als Hilfe beim Aufsteigen. Es verbessert die Fähigkeit des Reiters, das Reittier zu kontrollieren, erheblich und erhöht so den Nutzen des Tieres bei der Kommunikation, beim Transport und in der Kriegsführung. Es gilt als eines der grundlegenden Werkzeuge zur Schaffung und Verbreitung der modernen Zivilisation. Manche behaupten, es sei genauso wichtig wie das Rad oder die Druckerpresse. [PARAGRAPH:2]Der Steigbügel wurde relativ spät in der Geschichte erfunden, wenn man bedenkt, dass Pferde etwa 4.500 v. Chr. domestiziert wurden. Die erste verlässliche Darstellung eines Reiters mit gepaarten Steigbügeln wurde in China in einem Grab der Jin-Dynastie aus dem Jahr 322 n. Chr. gefunden. Der Steigbügel verbreitete sich durch die Reiter der zentralasiatischen Steppen in ganz Eurasien. Die Griechen und Römer nutzten sie nicht, sondern montierten sie durch Gewölbe oder von einem Montageblock aus. Im 7. Jahrhundert verbreiteten sich Steigbügel vor allem dank Eindringlingen aus Zentralasien, wie den Mongolen, über Asien nach Europa. Im 8. Jahrhundert scheinen sie von den Europäern übernommen worden zu sein. In Mitteleuropa wurden Steigbügel erstmals während der Herrschaft von Karl Martell indirekt dokumentiert. [ABSATZ:2]Beim Einsatz von Pferden in der Kriegsführung war der Steigbügel nach dem Streitwagen und dem Sattel des berittenen Reiters der dritte revolutionäre Ausrüstungsschritt. Steigbügel veränderten die Grundtaktiken der berittenen Kriegsführung und machten die Kavallerie wichtiger. An die Steigbügel gestützt, konnte ein Ritter mit einer Lanze einen Schlag ausführen, bei dem das gesamte Gewicht und der Schwung von Pferd und Reiter zusammenkamen. Als Reaktion auf einen plötzlichen und dringenden Bedarf an Kavallerie befahl Karl der Große seinen ärmeren Vasallen, ihre Ressourcen zu bündeln und einen berittenen und bewaffneten Ritter zur Verfügung zu stellen. Durch das Hinzufügen von Steigbügeln konnte ein Reiter auch einen längeren (und wesentlich stärkeren) Bogen verwenden, indem er auf den Steigbügeln stand.

The first dependable representation of a rider with paired stirrups was found in China in a Jin Dynasty tomb of about 322 AD. The stirrup spread throughout Eurasia by the horsemen of the central Asian steppes. The Greeks and Romans did not use them but mounted by vaulting or from a mounting block. By the 7th century, thanks primarily to invaders from Central Asia, such as the Mongols, stirrups spread across Asia to Europe. By the 8th century, they appear to have been adopted by the Europeans. Stirrups were first indirectly documented in Central Europe during the reign of Charles Martel. [PARAGRAPH:2]In the use of horses in warfare, the stirrup was the third revolutionary step in equipment, after the chariot and the saddle of the mounted horseman. Stirrups changed the basic tactics of mounted warfare and made cavalry more important. Braced against the stirrups, a knight could deliver a blow with a lance that employed the full weight and momentum of horse and rider together. Reacting to a sudden and urgent demand for cavalry, Charlemagne ordered his poorer vassals to pool their resources and provide a mounted and armed knight. The addition of stirrups also allowed a rider to use a longer (and vastly more powerful) bow by standing up on the stirrups.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]The stirrup is a ring with a flat bottom fixed on a leather strap, usually hung from each side of a saddle to create a footrest for the rider on a riding animal (usually a horse or other equine, such as mule), suspended by an adjustable strap from the saddle for use as a support for the foot of a rider of a horse when seated in the saddle and as an aid in mounting. It greatly increases the rider's ability to control the mount, increasing the animal's usefulness in communication, transportation and warfare. It is considered one of the basic tools used to create and spread modern civilization. Some argue it is as important as the wheel or printing press. [PARAGRAPH:2]The stirrup was invented relatively late in history, considering that horses were domesticated approximately 4,500 BC. The first dependable representation of a rider with paired stirrups was found in China in a Jin Dynasty tomb of about 322 AD. The stirrup spread throughout Eurasia by the horsemen of the central Asian steppes. The Greeks and Romans did not use them but mounted by vaulting or from a mounting block. By the 7th century, thanks primarily to invaders from Central Asia, such as the Mongols, stirrups spread across Asia to Europe. By the 8th century, they appear to have been adopted by the Europeans. Stirrups were first indirectly documented in Central Europe during the reign of Charles Martel. [PARAGRAPH:2]In the use of horses in warfare, the stirrup was the third revolutionary step in equipment, after the chariot and the saddle of the mounted horseman. Stirrups changed the basic tactics of mounted warfare and made cavalry more important. Braced against the stirrups, a knight could deliver a blow with a lance that employed the full weight and momentum of horse and rider together. Reacting to a sudden and urgent demand for cavalry, Charlemagne ordered his poorer vassals to pool their resources and provide a mounted and armed knight. The addition of stirrups also allowed a rider to use a longer (and vastly more powerful) bow by standing up on the stirrups.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A vassal in the terminology that both preceded and accompanied the feudalism of medieval Europe, is one who enters into mutual obligations with a monarch, usually of military support and mutual protection, in exchange for certain guarantees, which came to include the terrain held as a fief.
TEXT.French: [TAB]A vassal in the terminology that both preceded and accompanied the feudalism of medieval Europe, is one who enters into mutual obligations with a monarch, usually of military support and mutual protection, in exchange for certain guarantees, which came to include the terrain held as a fief.

TEXT.English: [TAB]During the Middle Ages, archery in warfare was not as prevalent and dominant in Western Europe as popular myth dictates. Archers were quite often the lowest-paid soldiers in an army or were conscripted from the peasantry. This was due to the cheap nature of the bow and arrow, as compared to the expense needed to equip a professional man-at-arms with good armour and a sword. Professional archers required a lifetime of training and expensive bows to be effective, and were thus rare in Europe.
TEXT.French: [TAB]During the Middle Ages, archery in warfare was not as prevalent and dominant in Western Europe as popular myth dictates. Professional archers required a lifetime of training and expensive bows to be effective, and were thus rare in Europe.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Während des Mittelalters war das Bogenschießen in der Kriegsführung in Westeuropa nicht so weit verbreitet und vorherrschend, wie der populäre Mythos vorgibt. Bogenschützen waren oft die am schlechtesten bezahlten Soldaten einer Armee oder wurden aus der Bauernschaft rekrutiert. Dies lag an der billigen Beschaffenheit von Pfeil und Bogen im Vergleich zu den Kosten, die für die Ausrüstung eines professionellen Heerführers mit einer guten Rüstung und einem Schwert anfallen. Professionelle Bogenschützen benötigten eine lebenslange Ausbildung und teure Bögen, um effektiv zu sein, und waren daher in Europa selten.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Medieval European knights attacked in several different ways, implementing shock tactics if possible, but always in formations of several knights, not individually. For defense and melee a formation of horsemen was as tight as possible next to each other in a line. This preventing their enemy from charging, and also from surrounding them individually. With their heavy and armoured chargers knights trampled through the enemy infantry. The most devastating charging method was to ride in a looser formation fast into attack. This attack was often protected by simultaneous or shortly preceding ranged attacks of archers or crossbowmen. The attack began from a distance of about 350 metres and took about 15-20 seconds to cross the contemporary long range weapon's effective distance. A most important element, and one not easily mastered, was to stay in one line with fixed spaces while accelerating and having the maximum speed at impact. Often knights would come in several waves, with the first being the best equipped and armored. The lance as primary weapon pierced the enemy. If an enemy soldier was hit in full gallop by a knight's lance embedded under the armpit, he was thrown backwards with such a momentum that he knocked over several of his compatriots. The heavy lances were dropped after the attack and the battle was continued with secondary weapons (sword, axe, mace or likewise).
TEXT.French: [TAB]Medieval European knights attacked in several different ways, implementing shock tactics if possible, but always in formations of several knights, not individually. For defense and melee a formation of horsemen was as tight as possible next to each other in a line. This preventing their enemy from charging, and also from surrounding them individually. With their heavy and armoured chargers knights trampled through the enemy infantry. The most devastating charging method was to ride in a looser formation fast into attack. This attack was often protected by simultaneous or shortly preceding ranged attacks of archers or crossbowmen. The attack began from a distance of about 350 metres and took about 15-20 seconds to cross the contemporary long range weapon's effective distance. A most important element, and one not easily mastered, was to stay in one line with fixed spaces while accelerating and having the maximum speed at impact. Often knights would come in several waves, with the first being the best equipped and armored. The lance as primary weapon pierced the enemy. If an enemy soldier was hit in full gallop by a knight's lance embedded under the armpit, he was thrown backwards with such a momentum that he knocked over several of his compatriots. The heavy lances were dropped after the attack and the battle was continued with secondary weapons (sword, axe, mace or likewise).
TEXT.German: [TAB]Mittelalterliche europäische Ritter griffen auf unterschiedliche Weise an und verwendeten, wenn möglich, Schocktaktiken, aber immer in Formationen mehrerer Ritter, nicht einzeln. Zur Verteidigung und zum Nahkampf wurde eine Reiterformation möglichst dicht nebeneinander in einer Linie aufgestellt. Dies verhindert, dass der Feind angreift und ihn einzeln umzingelt. Mit ihren schweren und gepanzerten Streitrossen zertrampelten die Ritter die feindliche Infanterie. Die verheerendste Angriffsmethode bestand darin, in einer lockeren Formation schnell in den Angriff zu reiten. Dieser Angriff wurde oft durch gleichzeitige oder kurz vorhergehende Fernangriffe von Bogenschützen oder Armbrustschützen geschützt. Der Angriff begann aus einer Entfernung von etwa 350 Metern und dauerte etwa 15 bis 20 Sekunden, um die effektive Reichweite moderner Langstreckenwaffen zu überschreiten. Ein äußerst wichtiges und nicht leicht zu beherrschendes Element bestand darin, beim Beschleunigen in einer Linie mit festen Abständen zu bleiben und beim Aufprall die maximale Geschwindigkeit zu erreichen. Oft kamen Ritter in mehreren Wellen, wobei die erste die am besten ausgerüstete und gepanzerte war. Die Lanze als Hauptwaffe durchbohrte den Feind. Wurde ein feindlicher Soldat im vollen Galopp von einer unter der Achselhöhle eingelassenen Ritterlanze getroffen, wurde er mit solcher Wucht nach hinten geschleudert, dass er mehrere seiner Landsleute umwarf. Nach dem Angriff wurden die schweren Lanzen abgeworfen und der Kampf mit Sekundärwaffen (Schwert, Axt, Streitkolben o.ä.) fortgesetzt.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The first bridges were spans made of wooden logs or planks and eventually stones, using a simple support and crossbeam arrangement. The arch was first used by the Roman Empire for bridges and aqueducts, some of which still stand today. Much of the Roman knowledge disappeared during the Dark Ages, but was gradually rediscovered in the Middle Ages.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Die ersten Brücken waren Spannweiten aus Holzstämmen oder Brettern und schließlich Steinen, die eine einfache Anordnung aus Stützen und Querträgern verwendeten. Der Bogen wurde erstmals vom Römischen Reich für Brücken und Aquädukte genutzt, von denen einige noch heute stehen. Ein Großteil des römischen Wissens verschwand im Mittelalter, wurde aber im Mittelalter nach und nach wiederentdeckt.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Mosaic is the art of creating images with an assemblage of small pieces of colored glass, stone, or other materials. Mosaics have been used to decorate buildings, especially those of religious nature, by most major cultures, but they were of particular importance in Byzantine, Persian and Islamic art. Walls and domes of the Palace of Constantinople, Hagia Sophia, the Dome of the Rock, the Umayyad Mosque and the Shah Mosque were all extensively covered by mosaics.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Mosaic is the art of creating images with an assemblage of small pieces of colored glass, stone, or other materials. Mosaics have been used to decorate buildings, especially those of religious nature, by most major cultures, but they were of particular importance in Byzantine, Persian and Islamic art. Walls and domes of the Palace of Constantinople, Hagia Sophia, the Dome of the Rock, the Umayyad Mosque and the Shah Mosque were all extensively covered by mosaics.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Mosaik ist die Kunst, Bilder aus einer Zusammenstellung kleiner Stücke aus farbigem Glas, Stein oder anderen Materialien zu erstellen. Mosaike wurden von den meisten großen Kulturen zur Dekoration von Gebäuden verwendet, insbesondere von Gebäuden religiöser Natur, waren jedoch in der byzantinischen, persischen und islamischen Kunst von besonderer Bedeutung. Wände und Kuppeln des Palastes von Konstantinopel, der Hagia Sophia, des Felsendoms, der Umayyaden-Moschee und der Schah-Moschee waren alle großflächig mit Mosaiken bedeckt.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The word "philosophy" comes from a Greek term meaning "love of wisdom." In ancient Greece, literacy and an interest in the natural world were common in a burgeoning upper class. In their leisure time, these people contemplated principles of thinking and being, logic and mathematics, and the natures of reality and existence. In ancient times, the study of philosophy was indistinguishable from the study of science, and many of the theories formulated by the early philosophers became the basis for studies in the fields of astronomy, medicine, chemistry, and physics. The teachings and writings of the ancient philosophers of Greece and the Orient also, in part, laid the groundwork for many of the world's oldest organized religions.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The word "philosophy" comes from a Greek term meaning "love of wisdom." In ancient Greece, literacy and an interest in the natural world were common in a burgeoning upper class. In their leisure time, these people contemplated principles of thinking and being, logic and mathematics, and the natures of reality and existence. In ancient times, the study of philosophy was indistinguishable from the study of science, and many of the theories formulated by the early philosophers became the basis for studies in the fields of astronomy, medicine, chemistry, and physics. The teachings and writings of the ancient philosophers of Greece and the Orient also, in part, laid the groundwork for many of the world's oldest organized religions.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der Begriff Philosophie kommt aus dem Griechischen und bedeutet etwa so viel wie "Weisheitsliebe". In der Oberklasse des antiken Griechenlands waren sowohl die Fähigkeit, lesen und schreiben zu können, als auch das Interesse an der Natur eine Selbstverständlichkeit. Diese Leute verbrachten ihre Freizeit damit, über das Denken und das Sein, die Logik, die Mathematik sowie die Bedeutung von Realität und Existenz zu philosophieren. In der Antike wurde nicht zwischen den Lehren der Philosophie und der Wissenschaften unterschieden, so dass viele Theorien der frühen Philosophen später auch als Grundlage für die Studien auf den Gebieten der Astronomie, der Medizin, der Chemie und der Physik dienten. Sogar die ältesten Religionen der Welt basieren zum Teil auf den Lehren und Schriften der frühen Philosophen Griechenlands und des Orients.

TEXT.English: [TAB]In religion and spirituality, a pilgrimage is a long journey or search of great moral significance. Sometimes, it is a journey to a sacred place or shrine of importance to a person's beliefs and faith. Members of every major religion participate in pilgrimages. A person who makes such a journey is called a pilgrim. [PARAGRAPH:2]In the Middle Ages, even as early as the 4th century AD, Christian pilgrimage was regarded as a sacred obligation and a trial of one's faith, since travel was dangerous, expensive and time-consuming. A returning pilgrim was called a palmer, as they would wear two crossed palm leaves to show they had made the pilgrimage. [PARAGRAPH:2]Pilgrimage to Mecca  the hajj  is one of the Five Pillars of Islam. It should be attempted at least once in the lifetime of all able-bodied Muslims who can afford. [PARAGRAPH:2]Pilgrims contributed an important element to long-distance trade before the modern era, and brought prosperity to successful pilgrimage sites, an economic phenomenon unequalled until the tourist trade of the 20th century. Encouraging pilgrims was a motivation for assembling (and sometimes fabricating) relics and for writing hagiographies of local saints, filled with inspiring accounts of miracle cures. Lourdes and other modern pilgrimage sites keep this spirit alive.

[PARAGRAPH:2]Pilgrimage to Mecca  the hajj  is one of the Five Pillars of Islam. It should be attempted at least once in the lifetime of all able-bodied Muslims who can afford. [PARAGRAPH:2]Pilgrims contributed an important element to long-distance trade before the modern era, and brought prosperity to successful pilgrimage sites, an economic phenomenon unequalled until the tourist trade of the 20th century. Encouraging pilgrims was a motivation for assembling (and sometimes fabricating) relics and for writing hagiographies of local saints, filled with inspiring accounts of miracle cures. Lourdes and other modern pilgrimage sites keep this spirit alive.
TEXT.German: [TAB]In Religion und Spiritualität ist eine Pilgerreise eine lange Reise oder Suche von großer moralischer Bedeutung. Manchmal handelt es sich um eine Reise zu einem heiligen Ort oder Schrein, der für den Glauben einer Person von Bedeutung ist. Mitglieder aller großen Religionen nehmen an Pilgerfahrten teil. Eine Person, die eine solche Reise unternimmt, wird Pilger genannt. [PARAGRAPH:2]Im Mittelalter, bereits im 4. Jahrhundert n. Chr., galt die christliche Pilgerfahrt als heilige Verpflichtung und Prüfung des eigenen Glaubens, da das Reisen gefährlich, teuer und zeitaufwändig war. Ein zurückkehrender Pilger wurde Palmer genannt, da er zwei gekreuzte Palmblätter trug, um zu zeigen, dass er die Pilgerreise unternommen hatte. [ABSATZ:2]Die Pilgerfahrt nach Mekka - der Hadsch - ist eine der fünf Säulen des Islam. Es sollte von allen arbeitsfähigen Muslimen, die es sich leisten können, mindestens einmal im Leben versucht werden. [PARAGRAPH:2]Pilger leisteten einen wichtigen Beitrag zum Fernhandel vor der Neuzeit und brachten erfolgreichen Pilgerorten Wohlstand, ein wirtschaftliches Phänomen, das bis zum Tourismus des 20. Jahrhunderts seinesgleichen suchte. Die Ermutigung der Pilger war eine Motivation für die Zusammenstellung (und manchmal auch die Herstellung) von Reliquien und für das Verfassen von Hagiographien lokaler Heiliger, gefüllt mit inspirierenden Berichten über Wunderheilungen. Lourdes und andere moderne Wallfahrtsorte halten diesen Geist am Leben.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]In religion and spirituality, a pilgrimage is a long journey or search of great moral significance. Sometimes, it is a journey to a sacred place or shrine of importance to a person's beliefs and faith. Members of every major religion participate in pilgrimages. A person who makes such a journey is called a pilgrim. [PARAGRAPH:2]In the Middle Ages, even as early as the 4th century AD, Christian pilgrimage was regarded as a sacred obligation and a trial of one's faith, since travel was dangerous, expensive and time-consuming. A returning pilgrim was called a palmer, as they would wear two crossed palm leaves to show they had made the pilgrimage. [PARAGRAPH:2]Pilgrimage to Mecca  the hajj  is one of the Five Pillars of Islam. It should be attempted at least once in the lifetime of all able-bodied Muslims who can afford. [PARAGRAPH:2]Pilgrims contributed an important element to long-distance trade before the modern era, and brought prosperity to successful pilgrimage sites, an economic phenomenon unequalled until the tourist trade of the 20th century. Encouraging pilgrims was a motivation for assembling (and sometimes fabricating) relics and for writing hagiographies of local saints, filled with inspiring accounts of miracle cures. Lourdes and other modern pilgrimage sites keep this spirit alive.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A levy (plural levies) is a military force raised ("levied") in a particular manner. In the Roman legion this typically means "farmer soldier" militia units raised by conscription that provided most of light and heavy infantry composition-most of which were of poor training and little fighting ability-but not always. In the British Empire, levies were units raised by local officials for local tasks, typically for local order and security.
TEXT.French: [TAB]A levy (plural levies) is a military force raised ("levied") in a particular manner. In the British Empire, levies were units raised by local officials for local tasks, typically for local order and security.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ein Rekrut ist eine militärische Kraft, die auf eine bestimmte Weise erhoben ("erhoben") wird. In der römischen Legion bedeutet dies in der Regel durch Einberufung aufgestellte "Bauernsoldaten"-Milizeinheiten, die den Großteil der leichten und schweren Infanterietruppe stellten - die meisten von ihnen waren schlecht ausgebildet und hatten geringe Kampffähigkeiten -, aber nicht immer. Im britischen Empire waren Abgaben Einheiten, die von örtlichen Beamten für örtliche Aufgaben, typischerweise für die örtliche Ordnung und Sicherheit, erhoben wurden.

TEXT.English: [TAB]After the collapse of the Roman Empire in Europe and the subsequent loss of the Legions, local nobles realized that the ordered tactics of the Romans were something better than the disorganized style of warfare of the Celts and other tribes that had preceded them and set about ways of emulating them. Since the bonds of kinship and local loyalty were more important to the average European than the bonds of nation-state, most medieval combat units were made up of people from one locality, under the command of a local noble. These local units were important to the areas they came from in that they could keep the incessant bandit raids that accompanied the collapse of the Empire, but could also be called up by a more powerful noble to operate in an army if one was needed. These units were trained in various combat maneuvers and operated with discipline that, while not up to Legionary standards, was still a far cry from the wild screaming charge that was the hallmark of ancient warfare in Europe, and the addition of heavy armor to common infantry troops, until this period unthinkable in Europe, was a dramatic leap forward for unit survivability. This step in military organization led to a non-noble warrior culture in Europe and paved the way for standing professional armies.
TEXT.French: [TAB]After the collapse of the Roman Empire in Europe and the subsequent loss of the Legions, local nobles realized that the ordered tactics of the Romans were something better than the disorganized style of warfare of the Celts and other tribes that had preceded them and set about ways of emulating them. These local units were important to the areas they came from in that they could keep the incessant bandit raids that accompanied the collapse of the Empire, but could also be called up by a more powerful noble to operate in an army if one was needed. These units were trained in various combat maneuvers and operated with discipline that, while not up to Legionary standards, was still a far cry from the wild screaming charge that was the hallmark of ancient warfare in Europe, and the addition of heavy armor to common infantry troops, until this period unthinkable in Europe, was a dramatic leap forward for unit survivability. This step in military organization led to a non-noble warrior culture in Europe and paved the way for standing professional armies.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Nach dem Zusammenbruch des Römischen Reiches in Europa und dem anschließenden Verlust der Legionen erkannten die örtlichen Adligen, dass die geordnete Taktik der Römer etwas Besseres war als der unorganisierte Kriegsstil der Kelten und anderer Stämme, der ihnen vorausgegangen war Überlegen Sie, wie Sie sie nachahmen können. Da Verwandtschaftsbande und lokale Loyalität für den Durchschnittseuropäer wichtiger waren als die Bande eines Nationalstaates, bestanden die meisten mittelalterlichen Kampfeinheiten aus Menschen eines Ortes unter dem Kommando eines örtlichen Adligen. Diese lokalen Einheiten waren für die Gebiete, aus denen sie kamen, wichtig, da sie die unaufhörlichen Banditenüberfälle, die mit dem Zusammenbruch des Imperiums einhergingen, abwehren konnten, aber auch von einem mächtigeren Adligen einberufen werden konnten, um bei Bedarf in einer Armee zu operieren. Diese Einheiten wurden in verschiedenen Kampfmanövern geschult und operierten mit einer Disziplin, die zwar nicht den Standards der Legionäre entsprach, aber immer noch weit entfernt war von dem wilden, schreienden Angriff, der das Markenzeichen der antiken Kriegsführung in Europa war, und der Hinzufügung schwerer Panzerung zur gewöhnlichen Infanterie Truppen, die bis zu diesem Zeitpunkt in Europa undenkbar waren, stellten einen dramatischen Fortschritt für die Überlebensfähigkeit der Einheiten dar. Dieser Schritt in der militärischen Organisation führte zu einer nichtadligen Kriegerkultur in Europa und ebnete den Weg für stehende Berufsarmeen.

TEXT.English: Plantation
TEXT.French: Plantation
TEXT.German: Plantage
TEXT.Italian: Plantation
TEXT.Spanish: Plantation

TEXT.English: [TAB]A plantation is an intentional planting of a crop, on a larger scale, usually for uses other than cereal production or pasture. The term is most often used for plantings of trees and shrubs. The term tends also to be used for plantings maintained on economic bases other than that of subsistence farming. Crops may be called plantation crops because of their association with a specific type of farming economy. Most of these involve a large landowner, raising crops with economic value rather than for subsistence, with a number of employees carrying out the work. Often it referred to crops newly introduced to a region. In past times it has been associated with slavery, indentured labour, and other economic models of high inequity. However, arable and dairy farming are both usually (but not always) excluded from such definitions. A comparable economic structure in antiquity was the latifundia that produced commercial quantities of olive oil or wine, for export.
TEXT.French: [TAB]A plantation is an intentional planting of a crop, on a larger scale, usually for uses other than cereal production or pasture. The term is most often used for plantings of trees and shrubs. The term tends also to be used for plantings maintained on economic bases other than that of subsistence farming. Crops may be called plantation crops because of their association with a specific type of farming economy. Most of these involve a large landowner, raising crops with economic value rather than for subsistence, with a number of employees carrying out the work. Often it referred to crops newly introduced to a region. In past times it has been associated with slavery, indentured labour, and other economic models of high inequity. However, arable and dairy farming are both usually (but not always) excluded from such definitions. A comparable economic structure in antiquity was the latifundia that produced commercial quantities of olive oil or wine, for export.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Eine Plantage ist die absichtliche Anpflanzung einer Kulturpflanze in größerem Umfang, in der Regel für andere Zwecke als die Getreideproduktion oder als Weideland. Der Begriff wird am häufigsten für das Pflanzen von Bäumen und Sträuchern verwendet. Der Begriff wird tendenziell auch für Anpflanzungen verwendet, die auf anderen wirtschaftlichen Grundlagen als der Subsistenzwirtschaft betrieben werden. Nutzpflanzen können aufgrund ihrer Verbindung mit einer bestimmten Art der Agrarwirtschaft als Plantagenkulturen bezeichnet werden. Bei den meisten davon handelt es sich um einen Großgrundbesitzer, der Feldfrüchte mit wirtschaftlichem Wert und nicht für den Lebensunterhalt anbaut, wobei eine Reihe von Mitarbeitern die Arbeiten ausführen. Oftmals bezog er sich auf Nutzpflanzen, die in einer Region neu eingeführt wurden. In der Vergangenheit wurde es mit Sklaverei, Vertragsarbeit und anderen Wirtschaftsmodellen hoher Ungleichheit in Verbindung gebracht. Allerdings sind Ackerbau und Milchwirtschaft normalerweise (aber nicht immer) von solchen Definitionen ausgenommen. Eine vergleichbare Wirtschaftsstruktur in der Antike waren die Latifundien, die kommerzielle Mengen Olivenöl oder Wein für den Export produzierten.

TEXT.English: Silk Road
TEXT.French: Silk Road
TEXT.German: Seidenstraße
TEXT.Italian: Silk Road
TEXT.Spanish: Silk Road

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Mongol expansion throughout the Asian continent from around 1215 to 1360 helped bring political stability and re-establish the Silk Road. In the late 13th century, a Venetian explorer named Marco Polo became one of the first Europeans to travel the Silk Road to China. Westerners became more aware of the Far East when Polo documented his travels in Il Milione. He was followed by numerous Christian missionnaries to the East, such as William of Rubruck, Benedykt Polak, Giovanni da Pian del Carpini, Andrew of Longjumeau, Odoric of Pordenone, Giovanni de Marignolli, Giovanni di Monte Corvino, and other travellers such as Ibn Battuta or Niccolo Da Conti. Luxury goods were traded from one middleman to another, from China to the West, resulting in high prices for the trade goods. [PARAGRAPH:2]Many technological innovations from the East seem to have filtered into Europe around that time. The period of the High Middle Ages in Europe saw major technological advances, including the adoption through the Silk Road of printing, gunpowder, and the compass.
