In the late 13th century, a Venetian explorer named Marco Polo became one of the first Europeans to travel the Silk Road to China. Westerners became more aware of the Far East when Polo documented his travels in Il Milione. He was followed by numerous Christian missionnaries to the East, such as William of Rubruck, Benedykt Polak, Giovanni da Pian del Carpini, Andrew of Longjumeau, Odoric of Pordenone, Giovanni de Marignolli, Giovanni di Monte Corvino, and other travellers such as Ibn Battuta or Niccolo Da Conti. Luxury goods were traded from one middleman to another, from China to the West, resulting in high prices for the trade goods. [PARAGRAPH:2]Many technological innovations from the East seem to have filtered into Europe around that time. The period of the High Middle Ages in Europe saw major technological advances, including the adoption through the Silk Road of printing, gunpowder, and the compass.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die mongolische Expansion auf dem gesamten asiatischen Kontinent von etwa 1215 bis 1360 trug zur politischen Stabilität und zur Wiederherstellung der Seidenstraße bei. Im späten 13. Jahrhundert reiste ein venezianischer Entdecker namens Marco Polo als einer der ersten Europäer über die Seidenstraße nach China. Westler wurden auf den Fernen Osten aufmerksam, als Polo seine Reisen in Il Milione dokumentierte. Ihm folgten zahlreiche christliche Missionare im Osten, wie Wilhelm von Rubrück, Benedykt Polak, Giovanni da Pian del Carpini, Andreas von Longjumeau, Odoric von Pordenone, Giovanni de Marignolli, Giovanni di Monte Corvino und andere Reisende wie Ibn Battuta oder Niccolo Da Conti. Luxusgüter wurden von einem Zwischenhändler zum anderen gehandelt, von China in den Westen, was zu hohen Preisen für die Handelsgüter führte. [PARAGRAPH:2]Viele technologische Innovationen aus dem Osten scheinen zu dieser Zeit nach Europa gelangt zu sein. In der Zeit des Hochmittelalters gab es in Europa große technologische Fortschritte, darunter die Einführung von Buchdruck, Schießpulver und Kompass über die Seidenstraße.

TEXT.English: Long-distance Trade
TEXT.French: Long-distance Trade
TEXT.German: Fernhandel
TEXT.Italian: Long-distance Trade
TEXT.Spanish: Long-distance Trade

TEXT.English: "I had bought from an Iraqi merchant in Ghazna about thirty horses and a camel... This merchant went off to Khurasan and on returning to India received his money from me. He made an enormous profit." - Ibn Battuta
TEXT.French: "I had bought from an Iraqi merchant in Ghazna about thirty horses and a camel... This merchant went off to Khurasan and on returning to India received his money from me. He made an enormous profit." - Ibn Battuta

TEXT.Spanish: "I had bought from an Iraqi merchant in Ghazna about thirty horses and a camel... This merchant went off to Khurasan and on returning to India received his money from me. He made an enormous profit." - Ibn Battuta

TEXT.English: [TAB]At the beginning of the Renaissance, the key to long-distance trade was in the Mediterranean. Access to the Chinese and Indian markets passed through Muslim lands controlled by either Arabs or Turks. Europeans called all of the trade that flowed from that direction the Levant trade, their term for the Middle East in general. The situation made shipments precarious, since Christians and Muslims had been fighting in the Middle East since the Crusades in the eleventh century. Until 1450, there was only one Christian outpost in the eastern Mediterranean, Constantinople (now Istanbul). When that city fell to the Ottoman Turks in 1453, many Europeans feared that they would be permanently cut off from important luxury goods.
TEXT.French: [TAB]At the beginning of the Renaissance, the key to long-distance trade was in the Mediterranean. Access to the Chinese and Indian markets passed through Muslim lands controlled by either Arabs or Turks. Europeans called all of the trade that flowed from that direction the Levant trade, their term for the Middle East in general. The situation made shipments precarious, since Christians and Muslims had been fighting in the Middle East since the Crusades in the eleventh century. Until 1450, there was only one Christian outpost in the eastern Mediterranean, Constantinople (now Istanbul). When that city fell to the Ottoman Turks in 1453, many Europeans feared that they would be permanently cut off from important luxury goods.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Zu Beginn der Renaissance lag der Schlüssel zum Fernhandel im Mittelmeerraum. Der Zugang zu den chinesischen und indischen Märkten erfolgte über muslimische Länder, die entweder von Arabern oder Türken kontrolliert wurden. Die Europäer nannten den gesamten Handel, der aus dieser Richtung floss, "Levantenhandel", ihre Bezeichnung für den Nahen Osten im Allgemeinen. Die Situation machte die Lieferungen prekär, da Christen und Muslime seit den Kreuzzügen im 11. Jahrhundert im Nahen Osten kämpften. Bis 1450 gab es im östlichen Mittelmeerraum nur einen christlichen Außenposten: Konstantinopel (heute Istanbul). Als diese Stadt 1453 an die osmanischen Türken fiel, befürchteten viele Europäer, dass sie dauerhaft von wichtigen Luxusgütern abgeschnitten sein würden.

Access to the Chinese and Indian markets passed through Muslim lands controlled by either Arabs or Turks. Europeans called all of the trade that flowed from that direction the Levant trade, their term for the Middle East in general. The situation made shipments precarious, since Christians and Muslims had been fighting in the Middle East since the Crusades in the eleventh century. Until 1450, there was only one Christian outpost in the eastern Mediterranean, Constantinople (now Istanbul). When that city fell to the Ottoman Turks in 1453, many Europeans feared that they would be permanently cut off from important luxury goods.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]At the beginning of the Renaissance, the key to long-distance trade was in the Mediterranean. Access to the Chinese and Indian markets passed through Muslim lands controlled by either Arabs or Turks. Europeans called all of the trade that flowed from that direction the Levant trade, their term for the Middle East in general. The situation made shipments precarious, since Christians and Muslims had been fighting in the Middle East since the Crusades in the eleventh century. Until 1450, there was only one Christian outpost in the eastern Mediterranean, Constantinople (now Istanbul). When that city fell to the Ottoman Turks in 1453, many Europeans feared that they would be permanently cut off from important luxury goods.

TEXT.English: "What gunpowder did for war, the printing press has done for the mind." - Wendell Phillips
TEXT.French: "What gunpowder did for war, the printing press has done for the mind." - Wendell Phillips
TEXT.German: "Was das Schießpulver für den Krieg war, ist die Druckerpresse für den Geist." - Wendell Phillips
TEXT.Italian: "What gunpowder did for war, the printing press has done for the mind." - Wendell Phillips
TEXT.Spanish: "What gunpowder did for war, the printing press has done for the mind." - Wendell Phillips

TEXT.English: [TAB]Movable type is the system of printing and typography that uses movable components to reproduce the elements of a document. The world's first known movable type system for printing was created in China around 1040 AD. Printing using movable type spread from China to Central Asia during the Mongol Empire (1206-1405).

Das weltweit erste bekannte bewegliche Letternsystem für den Druck wurde um 1040 n. Chr. in China entwickelt. Der Druck mit beweglichen Lettern verbreitete sich während des Mongolenreichs (1206-1405) von China nach Zentralasien.

TEXT.English: Companies
TEXT.French: Companies
TEXT.German: Unternehmen
TEXT.Italian: Companies
TEXT.Spanish: Companies

TEXT.English: "I shall give it to you in two words: buy cheap and sell dear. There is commerce for you." - Ibn Khaldun, the Muqaddimah
TEXT.French: "I shall give it to you in two words: buy cheap and sell dear. There is commerce for you." - Ibn Khaldun, the Muqaddimah
TEXT.German: "I shall give it to you in two words: buy cheap and sell dear. There is commerce for you." - Ibn Khaldun, the Muqaddimah
TEXT.Italian: "I shall give it to you in two words: buy cheap and sell dear. There is commerce for you." - Ibn Khaldun, the Muqaddimah
TEXT.Spanish: "I shall give it to you in two words: buy cheap and sell dear. There is commerce for you." - Ibn Khaldun, the Muqaddimah

TEXT.English: [TAB]Although some forms of companies are thought to have existed during Ancient Rome and Ancient Greece, the closest recognizable ancestors of the modern company did not appear until the second millennium. The first recognizable commercial associations were medieval guilds, where guild members agreed to abide by guild rules, but did not participate in ventures for common profit. The earliest forms of joint commercial enterprise under the lex mercatoria were in fact partnerships. But with the expansion of international trade, Royal charters were increasingly granted in Europe (notably in England and Holland) to merchant adventurers. The Royal charters usually conferred special privileges on the trading company (including, usually, some form of monopoly).
TEXT.French: [TAB]Although some forms of companies are thought to have existed during Ancient Rome and Ancient Greece, the closest recognizable ancestors of the modern company did not appear until the second millennium. The first recognizable commercial associations were medieval guilds, where guild members agreed to abide by guild rules, but did not participate in ventures for common profit. The earliest forms of joint commercial enterprise under the lex mercatoria were in fact partnerships. But with the expansion of international trade, Royal charters were increasingly granted in Europe (notably in England and Holland) to merchant adventurers. The Royal charters usually conferred special privileges on the trading company (including, usually, some form of monopoly).
TEXT.German: [TAB]Obwohl man annimmt, dass einige Unternehmensformen bereits im antiken Rom und im antiken Griechenland existierten, tauchten die nächsten erkennbaren Vorfahren des modernen Unternehmens erst im zweiten Jahrtausend auf. Die ersten erkennbaren Handelsvereinigungen waren mittelalterliche Zünfte, in denen sich die Zunftmitglieder zwar bereit erklärten, die Zunftregeln einzuhalten, sich aber nicht an Unternehmungen mit gemeinsamem Gewinn beteiligten. Die frühesten Formen gemeinsamer Handelsunternehmen im Rahmen der Lex mercatoria waren tatsächlich Personengesellschaften. Doch mit der Ausweitung des internationalen Handels wurden Handelsabenteurern in Europa (insbesondere in England und Holland) zunehmend königliche Urkunden gewährt. Die königlichen Urkunden gewährten dem Handelsunternehmen in der Regel besondere Privilegien (in der Regel einschließlich einer Art Monopol).

The Royal charters usually conferred special privileges on the trading company (including, usually, some form of monopoly).

TEXT.English: Blast Furnace
TEXT.French: Blast Furnace
TEXT.German: Hochofen
TEXT.Italian: Blast Furnace
TEXT.Spanish: Blast Furnace

TEXT.English: [TAB]A blast furnace is a type of metallurgical furnace used for smelting to produce industrial metals, generally iron. In a blast furnace, fuel and ore are continuously supplied through the top of the furnace, while air is blown into the bottom of the chamber, so that the chemical reactions take place throughout the furnace as the material moves downward. Blast furnances were used primarily to produce pig iron - the intermediate material needed for large-scale production of steel.
TEXT.French: [TAB]A blast furnace is a type of metallurgical furnace used for smelting to produce industrial metals, generally iron. In a blast furnace, fuel and ore are continuously supplied through the top of the furnace, while air is blown into the bottom of the chamber, so that the chemical reactions take place throughout the furnace as the material moves downward. Blast furnances were used primarily to produce pig iron - the intermediate material needed for large-scale production of steel.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ein Hochofen ist eine Art metallurgischer Ofen, der zum Schmelzen zur Herstellung von Industriemetallen, im Allgemeinen Eisen, verwendet wird. In einem Hochofen werden Brennstoff und Erz kontinuierlich durch die Oberseite des Ofens zugeführt, während Luft in den Boden der Kammer geblasen wird, sodass die chemischen Reaktionen im gesamten Ofen stattfinden, während sich das Material nach unten bewegt. Hochöfen dienten vor allem der Herstellung von Roheisen - dem Zwischenprodukt für die Stahlproduktion in großem Maßstab.

TEXT.English: Crop Rotation
TEXT.French: Crop Rotation
TEXT.German: Fruchtfolge
TEXT.Italian: Crop Rotation
TEXT.Spanish: Crop Rotation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Crop rotation is the practice of growing a series of dissimilar types of crops in the same space in sequential seasons to avoid the buildup of pathogens and pests that often occurs when one species is continuously cropped. Crop rotation also seeks to balance the fertility demands of various crops to avoid excessive depletion of soil nutrients. [PARAGRAPH:2]The ninth century saw the development of the three-field system of crop rotation: wheat or rye was planted in one field, the second field had a nitrogen-fixing crop (barley, oats, peas, or beans), and third was fallow. Compared to the earlier two-field system, a three-field system allowed for significantly more land to be put under cultivation. Even more important, the system allowed for two harvests a year, reducing the risk that a single crop failure would lead to famine. Three-field agriculture created a suplus of oats that could be used to feed horses. Because the system required a major rearrangement of real estate and the social order, it took until the 11th century before it came into general use.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Crop rotation is the practice of growing a series of dissimilar types of crops in the same space in sequential seasons to avoid the buildup of pathogens and pests that often occurs when one species is continuously cropped. Crop rotation also seeks to balance the fertility demands of various crops to avoid excessive depletion of soil nutrients. [PARAGRAPH:2]The ninth century saw the development of the three-field system of crop rotation: wheat or rye was planted in one field, the second field had a nitrogen-fixing crop (barley, oats, peas, or beans), and third was fallow. Compared to the earlier two-field system, a three-field system allowed for significantly more land to be put under cultivation. Even more important, the system allowed for two harvests a year, reducing the risk that a single crop failure would lead to famine. Three-field agriculture created a suplus of oats that could be used to feed horses. Because the system required a major rearrangement of real estate and the social order, it took until the 11th century before it came into general use.
TEXT.German: [TAB] Bei der Fruchtfolge handelt es sich um die Praxis, eine Reihe unterschiedlicher Arten von Kulturpflanzen in aufeinanderfolgenden Jahreszeiten auf demselben Raum anzubauen, um die Ansammlung von Krankheitserregern und Schädlingen zu vermeiden, die häufig auftritt, wenn eine Art kontinuierlich angebaut wird. Ziel der Fruchtfolge ist es außerdem, die Fruchtbarkeitsanforderungen verschiedener Kulturpflanzen auszugleichen, um eine übermäßige Erschöpfung der Bodennährstoffe zu vermeiden. [PARAGRAPH:2]Im neunten Jahrhundert entwickelte sich das Drei-Felder-System der Fruchtfolge: Auf einem Feld wurde Weizen oder Roggen gepflanzt, auf dem zweiten Feld gab es stickstoffbindende Nutzpflanzen (Gerste, Hafer, Erbsen oder Bohnen). und der dritte war brach. Im Vergleich zum früheren Zwei-Felder-System konnte mit einem Drei-Felder-System deutlich mehr Land bewirtschaftet werden. Noch wichtiger ist, dass das System zwei Ernten pro Jahr ermöglichte und so das Risiko verringerte, dass ein einziger Ernteausfall zu einer Hungersnot führen würde. Durch die Dreifelderwirtschaft entstand ein Überschuss an Hafer, der zur Pferdefütterung genutzt werden konnte. Da das System eine umfassende Neuordnung des Grundbesitzes und der sozialen Ordnung erforderte, dauerte es bis zum 11. Jahrhundert, bis es allgemein genutzt wurde.

Compared to the earlier two-field system, a three-field system allowed for significantly more land to be put under cultivation. Three-field agriculture created a suplus of oats that could be used to feed horses. Because the system required a major rearrangement of real estate and the social order, it took until the 11th century before it came into general use.

TEXT.English: Stern Rudder
TEXT.French: Stern Rudder
TEXT.German: Heckruder
TEXT.Italian: Stern Rudder
TEXT.Spanish: Stern Rudder

TEXT.English: [TAB]Ships in ancient times mostly had two rudders mounted aft on each side, the later Viking longships had one lateral rudder. The Hanseatic cogs in the Middle Ages, on the other hand, had a stern rudder. The first evidence from this period is a 13th-century wall drawing in the church of Fide (Gotland). The tiller of this rudder, which was much larger there, was moved with the Kolder stick, which served as an additional lever. The rudder is still known today from the Steinhuder Torfkahn. A central stern rudder was already found on the river boats of the Egyptians and Romans. The oldest find of a ship with a stern rudder is the Bremen Schlachte ship from 1100. Later ship types then had cable gears that moved the rudder from the steering wheel. Since the rudder for right-handed operation facing forward was usually attached to the right side of early sailing ships, the nautical term for this side of the ship was starboard.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Ships in ancient times mostly had two rudders mounted aft on each side, the later Viking longships had one lateral rudder. The Hanseatic cogs in the Middle Ages, on the other hand, had a stern rudder. The first evidence from this period is a 13th-century wall drawing in the church of Fide (Gotland). The tiller of this rudder, which was much larger there, was moved with the Kolder stick, which served as an additional lever. The rudder is still known today from the Steinhuder Torfkahn. A central stern rudder was already found on the river boats of the Egyptians and Romans. The oldest find of a ship with a stern rudder is the Bremen Schlachte ship from 1100. Later ship types then had cable gears that moved the rudder from the steering wheel. Since the rudder for right-handed operation facing forward was usually attached to the right side of early sailing ships, the nautical term for this side of the ship was starboard.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Schiffe in der Antike hatten zumeist zwei Ruder, die achtern an jeder Seite angebracht waren, die späteren Wikingerlangschiffe ein seitliches Ruder. Die Hansekoggen im Mittelalter hatten dagegen ein Heckruder. Der erste Beleg aus dieser Zeit ist eine Wandzeichnung aus dem 13.Jahrhundert in der Kirche von Fide (Gotland). Die Pinne dieses dort deutlich größeren Ruders wurde mit dem als zusätzlicher Hebel dienenden Kolderstock bewegt. Das Seitenruder ist heute noch beim Steinhuder Torfkahn bekannt. Ein zentrales Heckruder fand sich bereits bei den Flussschiffen der Ägypter und Römer. Der älteste Schiffsfund mit einem Heckruder ist das Bremer Schlachte-Schiff von 1100. Spätere Schiffstypen wiesen dann Seilgetriebe auf, die das Ruder vom Steuerrad aus bewegten. Da bei den frühen Segelschiffen das Seitenruder für die rechtshändige Bedienung mit Blick nach vorn üblicherweise auf der rechten Seite angebracht wurde, ergab sich für diese Schiffsseite die nautisch übliche Benennung Steuerbord.

The tiller of this rudder, which was much larger there, was moved with the Kolder stick, which served as an additional lever. The rudder is still known today from the Steinhuder Torfkahn. A central stern rudder was already found on the river boats of the Egyptians and Romans. The oldest find of a ship with a stern rudder is the Bremen Schlachte ship from 1100. Later ship types then had cable gears that moved the rudder from the steering wheel. Since the rudder for right-handed operation facing forward was usually attached to the right side of early sailing ships, the nautical term for this side of the ship was starboard.

TEXT.English: Castle Building
TEXT.French: Castle Building
TEXT.German: Burgenbau
TEXT.Italian: Castle Building
TEXT.Spanish: Castle Building

TEXT.English: [TAB]Castles served many functions in medieval Europe; not only were they formidable defensive positions, but they served as administrative and judicial centers and as the seat of a lord's power. Since food and supplies could be stockpiled at castles, castles exerted strong influence over very large surrounding territories. Secular lords were not the only ones to build castles; religious officials often did so as well, to provide themselves with stronger power bases. Early castles were usually little more than wooden stockades constructed on dirt mounds and perhaps surrounded by a shallow trench; by the time of the reign of Edward the Confessor in 13th century England, castle-building had become a much more elaborate affair, with hundreds of laborers and specialists constructing huge stone fortresses with intricate defenses in carefully selected geographic locations.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Castles served many functions in medieval Europe; not only were they formidable defensive positions, but they served as administrative and judicial centers and as the seat of a lord's power. Since food and supplies could be stockpiled at castles, castles exerted strong influence over very large surrounding territories. Secular lords were not the only ones to build castles; religious officials often did so as well, to provide themselves with stronger power bases. Early castles were usually little more than wooden stockades constructed on dirt mounds and perhaps surrounded by a shallow trench; by the time of the reign of Edward the Confessor in 13th century England, castle-building had become a much more elaborate affair, with hundreds of laborers and specialists constructing huge stone fortresses with intricate defenses in carefully selected geographic locations.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Burgen erfüllten im mittelalterlichen Europa viele Funktionen; Sie waren nicht nur beeindruckende Verteidigungsanlagen, sondern dienten auch als Verwaltungs- und Gerichtszentren sowie als Sitz der Macht eines Herrschers. Da in Burgen Lebensmittel und Vorräte gelagert werden konnten, übten Burgen einen starken Einfluss auf sehr große umliegende Gebiete aus. Weltliche Herren waren nicht die einzigen, die Burgen bauten; Oftmals taten dies auch religiöse Amtsträger, um sich eine stärkere Machtbasis zu verschaffen. Frühe Burgen waren in der Regel kaum mehr als hölzerne Palisaden, die auf Erdhügeln errichtet und vielleicht von einem flachen Graben umgeben waren; Zur Zeit der Herrschaft Eduards des Bekenners im England des 13. Jahrhunderts war der Burgbau zu einer viel aufwändigeren Angelegenheit geworden, da Hunderte von Arbeitern und Spezialisten an sorgfältig ausgewählten geografischen Standorten riesige Steinfestungen mit komplizierten Verteidigungsanlagen errichteten.

Since food and supplies could be stockpiled at castles, castles exerted strong influence over very large surrounding territories. TEXT.English: Cheque System
TEXT.French: Cheque System
TEXT.German: Schecksystem
TEXT.Italian: Cheque System
TEXT.Spanish: Cheque System

TEXT.English: [TAB]Beginning in the third century AD, banks in Persian territory began to issue letters of credit. These letters were termed cak, meaning "document" or "contract". The cak became the sakk later used by traders in the Abbasid Caliphate and other Arab-ruled lands. Transporting a paper sakk was more secure than transporting money. In the ninth century, a merchant in one country could cash a sakk drawn on his bank in another country. The Persian poet, Ferdowsi, used the term "cheque" several times in his famous book, Shahnameh, when referring to the Sasanid dynasty. Ibn Hawqal, living in the 10th century, records the use of a cheque written in Aoudaghost which was worth 42,000 dinars.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Beginning in the third century AD, banks in Persian territory began to issue letters of credit. These letters were termed cak, meaning "document" or "contract". The cak became the sakk later used by traders in the Abbasid Caliphate and other Arab-ruled lands. Transporting a paper sakk was more secure than transporting money. In the ninth century, a merchant in one country could cash a sakk drawn on his bank in another country. The Persian poet, Ferdowsi, used the term "cheque" several times in his famous book, Shahnameh, when referring to the Sasanid dynasty. Ibn Hawqal, living in the 10th century, records the use of a cheque written in Aoudaghost which was worth 42,000 dinars.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ab dem dritten Jahrhundert n. Chr. begannen Banken auf persischem Gebiet, Akkreditive auszustellen. Diese Briefe wurden cak genannt, was "Dokument" oder "Vertrag" bedeutet. Der cak wurde zum Sakk, der später von Händlern im abbasidischen Kalifat und anderen arabisch beherrschten Ländern verwendet wurde. Der Transport eines Papiersacks war sicherer als der Geldtransport. Im neunten Jahrhundert konnte ein Kaufmann in einem Land einen von seiner Bank in einem anderen Land gezogenen Sakk einlösen. Der persische Dichter Ferdowsi verwendete den Begriff "Scheck" in seinem berühmten Buch Shahnameh mehrmals, wenn er sich auf die Sasaniden-Dynastie bezog. Ibn Hawqal, der im 10. Jahrhundert lebte, berichtet von der Verwendung eines in Aoudaghost ausgestellten Schecks im Wert von 42.000 Dinar.

TEXT.English: Cash Cropping
TEXT.French: Cash Cropping
TEXT.German: Exportfrüchte
TEXT.Italian: Cash Cropping
TEXT.Spanish: Cash Cropping

TEXT.English: [TAB]A cash crop or profit crop is an agricultural crop which is grown to sell for profit. It is typically purchased by parties separate from a farm. The term is used to differentiate marketed crops from staple crop (or "subsistence crop") in subsistence agriculture, which are those fed to the producer's own livestock or grown as food for the producer's family.
TEXT.French: [TAB]A cash crop or profit crop is an agricultural crop which is grown to sell for profit. It is typically purchased by parties separate from a farm. The term is used to differentiate marketed crops from staple crop (or "subsistence crop") in subsistence agriculture, which are those fed to the producer's own livestock or grown as food for the producer's family.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Exportfrüchte oder Marktfrüchte sind landwirtschaftliche Nutzpflanzen, die angebaut werden, um sie mit Gewinn zu verkaufen. Der Erwerb erfolgt in der Regel durch Parteien außerhalb eines landwirtschaftlichen Betriebes. Der Begriff wird verwendet, um vermarktete Nutzpflanzen von Grundnahrungsmitteln (oder "Subsistenzfrüchten") in der Subsistenzlandwirtschaft zu unterscheiden, bei denen es sich um solche handelt, die an das eigene Vieh des Erzeugers verfüttert werden oder als Nahrungsmittel für die Familie des Erzeugers angebaut werden.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]A cash crop or profit crop is an agricultural crop which is grown to sell for profit. It is typically purchased by parties separate from a farm. The term is used to differentiate marketed crops from staple crop (or "subsistence crop") in subsistence agriculture, which are those fed to the producer's own livestock or grown as food for the producer's family.

TEXT.English: "A horse, a horse, my kingdom for a horse!" - Richard III by William Shakespeare
TEXT.French: "A horse, a horse, my kingdom for a horse!" - Richard III by William Shakespeare
TEXT.German: "A horse, a horse, my kingdom for a horse!" - Richard III by William Shakespeare
TEXT.Italian: "A horse, a horse, my kingdom for a horse!" - Richard III by William Shakespeare
TEXT.Spanish: "A horse, a horse, my kingdom for a horse!" - Richard III by William Shakespeare

TEXT.English: [TAB]Medieval Europe bred large horses specifically for war, called destriers. These horses were the ancestors of the great heavy horses of today, and their size was preferred not simply because of the weight of the armor, but also because a large horse provided more power for the knights lance. Weighing almost twice as much as a normal riding horse, the destrier was a powerful weapon in battle. [PARAGRAPH:2]On the other hand, during this same time, lighter horses were bred in northern Africa and the Middle East by Muslim warriors, who preferred a faster, more agile horse. The lighter horse suited the raids and battles of the Bedouins, allowing them to outmaneuver rather than overpower the enemy. When Muslim warriors and European knights collided in warfare, the heavy knights were frequently outmanuvered. The Europeans, however, soon made up for the lack of speed of their native breeds by adding hotter blood from captured oriental horses such as the Arabian, Barb to their stables. This cross-breeding led both to a nimbler war horse, such as today's Percheron, but also to created a type of horse known as a Courser, a predecessor to the Thoroughbred, which was used as a message horse.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Das mittelalterliche Europa züchtete große Pferde, sogenannte Destrier, speziell für den Krieg. Diese Pferde waren die Vorfahren der großen schweren Pferde von heute, und ihre Größe wurde nicht nur wegen des Gewichts der Rüstung bevorzugt, sondern auch, weil ein großes Pferd der Lanze des Ritters mehr Kraft verlieh. Mit einem Gewicht von fast doppelt so viel wie ein normales Reitpferd war das Destrier eine mächtige Waffe im Kampf. [PARAGRAPH:2]Andererseits wurden zur gleichen Zeit in Nordafrika und im Nahen Osten leichtere Pferde von muslimischen Kriegern gezüchtet, die ein schnelleres, agileres Pferd bevorzugten. Das leichtere Pferd eignete sich für die Überfälle und Schlachten der Beduinen und ermöglichte es ihnen, den Feind auszumanövrieren, anstatt ihn zu überwältigen. Wenn muslimische Krieger und europäische Ritter im Krieg aufeinandertrafen, wurden die schweren Ritter häufig ausmanövriert. Die Europäer machten die mangelnde Schnelligkeit ihrer einheimischen Rassen jedoch bald wett, indem sie ihren Ställen heißeres Blut von gefangenen orientalischen Pferden wie dem Araber Barb hinzufügten. Diese Kreuzung führte sowohl zu einem flinkeren Kriegspferd, wie dem heutigen Percheron, als auch zur Entstehung eines Pferdetyps namens Rennpferd, einem Vorläufer des Vollbluts, das als Nachrichtenpferd eingesetzt wurde.

TEXT.English: Shipbuilding
TEXT.French: Shipbuilding
TEXT.German: Schiffbau
TEXT.Italian: Shipbuilding
TEXT.Spanish: Shipbuilding

TEXT.English: [TAB]Ships were known in Europe since ancient time, but in the Middle Ages new types of shipbuilding developed. Viking longships developed from an alternate tradition of clinker-built hulls fastened with leather thongs. Sometime around the 12th century, northern European ships began to be built with a straight sternpost, enabling the mounting of a rudder, which was much more durable than a steering oar held over the side. Development in the Middle Ages favored "round ships", with a broad beam and heavily curved at both ends. The introduction of cannons onto ships encouraged the development of tumblehome, the inward slant of the abovewater hull, for additional stability, as well as techniques for strengthening the internal frame. This kind of considerations, as well as the demand for ships capable of operating safely in the open ocean, led to the documentation of design and construction practice in what had previously been a secretive trade, and ultimately the field of naval architecture.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Schiffe waren in Europa schon seit der Antike bekannt, doch im Mittelalter entwickelten sich neue Arten des Schiffbaus. Wikinger-Langschiffe entwickelten sich aus einer alternativen Tradition von Klinkerrümpfen, die mit Lederriemen befestigt wurden. Irgendwann um das 12. Jahrhundert begann man, nordeuropäische Schiffe mit einem geraden Heck zu bauen, was die Anbringung eines Ruders ermöglichte, das viel haltbarer war als ein über der Seite gehaltenes Steuerruder. Die Entwicklung im Mittelalter begünstigte "Rundschiffe", mit breiter Breite und stark gebogenen Enden. Die Einführung von Kanonen auf Schiffen förderte die Entwicklung von Tumblehome, der nach innen gerichteten Neigung des Überwasserrumpfs für zusätzliche Stabilität, sowie von Techniken zur Verstärkung des Innenrahmens. Diese Art von Überlegungen sowie die Nachfrage nach Schiffen, die sicher auf dem offenen Meer operieren können, führten zur Dokumentation der Entwurfs- und Baupraxis in einem zuvor geheimen Gewerbe und letztendlich im Bereich des Schiffsbaus.

TEXT.English: Organized Armies
TEXT.French: Organized Armies
TEXT.German: Organisiertes Heer
TEXT.Italian: Organized Armies
TEXT.Spanish: Organized Armies

TEXT.English: [TAB]During the Early Middle Ages, the major figure that changed the state and army organization was Charles Martel. Charles was a brilliant strategic general and tactical commander, able to adapt his plans mid-battle to the unforeseen and repeatedly defeat enemies, even, as at Tours, when they were far superior in men and weaponry. Charles used ground, time, place, and troop morale to offset his foes' superior weaponry and tactics. [PARAGRAPH:2]He was also a skilled administrator and ruler, organizing what would become the medieval European government - a system of fiefdoms, loyal to barons, counts, dukes and ultimately the King. His close coordination of church with state also began the medieval pattern for such government. He created the first western standing army since the fall of Rome. In essence, he changed western Europe from a horde of barbarians fighting with one another, to an organized state.

Charles used ground, time, place, and troop morale to offset his foes' superior weaponry and tactics. [PARAGRAPH:2]He was also a skilled administrator and ruler, organizing what would become the medieval European government - a system of fiefdoms, loyal to barons, counts, dukes and ultimately the King. His close coordination of church with state also began the medieval pattern for such government. He created the first western standing army since the fall of Rome. In essence, he changed western Europe from a horde of barbarians fighting with one another, to an organized state.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Im frühen Mittelalter war Karl Martel die wichtigste Persönlichkeit, die die Staats- und Heeresorganisation veränderte. Charles war ein brillanter strategischer General und taktischer Befehlshaber, der seine Pläne mitten in der Schlacht an Unvorhergesehenes anpassen und wiederholt Feinde besiegen konnte, selbst wenn diese, wie in Tours, an Männern und Waffen weit überlegen waren. Charles nutzte Boden, Zeit, Ort und Truppenmoral, um die überlegenen Waffen und Taktiken seiner Feinde auszugleichen. [PARAGRAPH:2]Er war auch ein geschickter Verwalter und Herrscher, der die spätere europäische Regierung des Mittelalters organisierte - ein System von Lehen, loyal gegenüber Baronen, Grafen, Herzögen und letztendlich dem König. Seine enge Koordination von Kirche und Staat begründete auch das mittelalterliche Muster einer solchen Regierung. Er stellte das erste stehende westliche Heer seit dem Fall Roms auf. Im Wesentlichen verwandelte er Westeuropa von einer Horde miteinander kämpfender Barbaren in einen organisierten Staat.

TEXT.English: "A person who can, within a year, solve x2 - 92y2 = 1 is a mathematician." - Brahmagupta

TEXT.English: [TAB]Algebra is a branch of mathematics concerning the study of structure, relation and quantity. The name is derived from the treatise written by the Persian mathematician Muhammad ibn Mu-sa- al-Khwa-rizmi titled "The Compendious Book on Calculation by Completion and Balancing", which provided symbolic operations for the systematic solution of linear and quadratic equations. [PARAGRAPH:2]Algebra was introduced to Europe largely through the work of Leonardo Fibonacci of Pisa in his work Liber Abaci.

Der Name leitet sich von der Abhandlung des persischen Mathematikers Muhammad ibn Mu-sa-al-Khwa-rizmi mit dem Titel "The Compendious Book on Calculation by Completion and Balancing" ab, die symbolische Operationen für die systematische Lösung linearer und quadratischer Gleichungen bereitstellte. [PARAGRAPH:2]Algebra wurde in Europa größtenteils durch die Arbeit von Leonardo Fibonacci von Pisa in seinem Werk Liber Abaci eingeführt.

TEXT.English: Military Drill
TEXT.French: Military Drill
TEXT.German: Drill
TEXT.Italian: Military Drill
TEXT.Spanish: Military Drill

TEXT.English: [TAB]A drill in military terms is the action of memorising a certain action through repetition until the action is instinctive to the soldiers being drilled. Such is necessary for a fighting force to perform to maximum efficiency and to be flexible to all manner of situations. As a whole, drilling as a vital component of a war machine started when Phillip II of Macedon disciplined his army so they could swiftly form the phalanxes that were so critical to his successes as a general. Military drilling later was used by the Roman Army to maximise efficiency and deadliness throughout their long history. After the fall of the empire, and the Dark Ages set in in Europe, most feudal lords more heaviliy relied on peasant levies and their wealthy knights to fight their wars, and military drilling was used mostly by only the foremost armies and nations, such as the Normans.
TEXT.French: [TAB]A drill in military terms is the action of memorising a certain action through repetition until the action is instinctive to the soldiers being drilled. Such is necessary for a fighting force to perform to maximum efficiency and to be flexible to all manner of situations. As a whole, drilling as a vital component of a war machine started when Phillip II of Macedon disciplined his army so they could swiftly form the phalanxes that were so critical to his successes as a general. Military drilling later was used by the Roman Army to maximise efficiency and deadliness throughout their long history. After the fall of the empire, and the Dark Ages set in in Europe, most feudal lords more heaviliy relied on peasant levies and their wealthy knights to fight their wars, and military drilling was used mostly by only the foremost armies and nations, such as the Normans.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ein Drill im militärischen Sinne ist die Aktion, sich eine bestimmte Aktion durch Wiederholung einzuprägen, bis die Aktion für die Soldaten, die trainiert werden, instinktiv ist. Dies ist notwendig, damit eine Kampftruppe maximale Effizienz erzielen und auf alle möglichen Situationen flexibel reagieren kann. Insgesamt begann das Drillen als wesentlicher Bestandteil einer Kriegsmaschinerie, als Philipp II. von Mazedonien seine Armee disziplinierte, damit sie schnell die Phalanxen bilden konnte, die für seine Erfolge als General so entscheidend waren. Militärübungen wurden später von der römischen Armee im Laufe ihrer langen Geschichte eingesetzt, um die Effizienz und Tödlichkeit zu maximieren. Nach dem Untergang des Reiches und dem Beginn des Mittelalters in Europa verließen sich die meisten Feudalherren bei der Führung ihrer Kriege stärker auf Bauernaushebungen und ihre wohlhabenden Ritter, und Militärübungen wurden meist nur von den führenden Armeen und Nationen durchgeführt, wie z die Normannen.

TEXT.English: Metallurgy
TEXT.French: Metallurgy
TEXT.German: Metallurgie
TEXT.Italian: Metallurgy
TEXT.Spanish: Metallurgy

TEXT.English: [TAB]Metallurgy is the study of the properties of metals and the methods used to separate metal deposits from metal-bearing ores. Through the course of history, artisans have switched the materials from which they constructed weapons and tools to harder, more durable metals as they were discovered. However, metallurgy as a science wasn't studied in earnest until the powers of Europe began to compete against one another in an attempt to design better and more effective weapons starting around the 14th century. Constant improvements in metallurgy led to the discovery of new metals and alloys that were stronger, lighter, and cheaper. As a result of this race for military dominance, Europeans produced some of the most advanced weaponry in the world during this time period.

As a result of this race for military dominance, Europeans produced some of the most advanced weaponry in the world during this time period.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Metallurgie ist die Untersuchung der Eigenschaften von Metallen und der Methoden zur Trennung von Metallvorkommen von metallhaltigen Erzen. Im Laufe der Geschichte haben Handwerker die Materialien, aus denen sie Waffen und Werkzeuge herstellten, auf härtere, haltbarere Metalle umgestellt, als diese entdeckt wurden. Allerdings wurde die Metallurgie als Wissenschaft erst im 14. Jahrhundert ernsthaft erforscht, als die Mächte Europas gegeneinander antraten, um bessere und effektivere Waffen zu entwickeln. Ständige Verbesserungen in der Metallurgie führten zur Entdeckung neuer Metalle und Legierungen, die fester, leichter und billiger waren. Als Ergebnis dieses Wettlaufs um die militärische Vorherrschaft stellten die Europäer in dieser Zeit einige der fortschrittlichsten Waffen der Welt her.

TEXT.English: Heavy Armor
TEXT.French: Heavy Armor
TEXT.German: Schwere Rüstung
TEXT.Italian: Heavy Armor
TEXT.Spanish: Heavy Armor

TEXT.English: [TAB]Plate armour protecting the chest and the lower limbs was used by the ancient Greeks and Romans, but it fell into disuse after the collapse of the Roman Empire. Single plates of metal armour were again used from the late 13th century on, to protect joints and shins, and these were worn over full mail haubergeons. By the end of the 14th century, larger and complete full plates of armour had been developed.

Single plates of metal armour were again used from the late 13th century on, to protect joints and shins, and these were worn over full mail haubergeons. By the end of the 14th century, larger and complete full plates of armour had been developed.

Ab dem späten 13. Jahrhundert wurden zum Schutz von Gelenken und Schienbeinen wieder einzelne Platten aus Metallpanzern verwendet, die über Kettenhemden getragen wurden. Bis zum Ende des 14. Jahrhunderts wurden größere und vollständige Vollpanzerplatten entwickelt.

TEXT.English: Canals
TEXT.French: Canals
TEXT.German: Kanäle
TEXT.Italian: Canals
TEXT.Spanish: Canals

TEXT.English: [TAB]Canals are man-made waterways, usually connected to (and sometimes connecting) existing lakes, rivers, or oceans. There are two main types of canals: irrigation canals for the delivery of water and transportation canals for passage of goods and people. Some canals are part of a waterway which is not entirely artificial (usually where a river has been canalised to make it navigable). Smaller transportation canals can carry barges or narrowboats, while ship canals allow sea-going ships to travel from one sea or ocean to another, or to an inland port.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Canals are man-made waterways, usually connected to (and sometimes connecting) existing lakes, rivers, or oceans. There are two main types of canals: irrigation canals for the delivery of water and transportation canals for passage of goods and people. Some canals are part of a waterway which is not entirely artificial (usually where a river has been canalised to make it navigable). Smaller transportation canals can carry barges or narrowboats, while ship canals allow sea-going ships to travel from one sea or ocean to another, or to an inland port.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Kanäle sind künstliche Wasserstraßen, die normalerweise mit bestehenden Seen, Flüssen oder Ozeanen verbunden sind (und manchmal auch diese verbinden). Es gibt zwei Haupttypen von Kanälen: Bewässerungskanäle für die Wasserversorgung und Transportkanäle für den Güter- und Personentransport. Einige Kanäle sind Teil einer Wasserstraße, die nicht vollständig künstlich angelegt ist (normalerweise dort, wo ein Fluss kanalisiert wurde, um ihn schiffbar zu machen). Kleinere Transportkanäle können Lastkähne oder Schmalboote befördern, während Schiffskanäle es Seeschiffen ermöglichen, von einem Meer oder Ozean zum anderen oder zu einem Binnenhafen zu fahren.

TEXT.English: Professional Armies
TEXT.French: Professional Armies
TEXT.German: Berufsarmeen
TEXT.Italian: Professional Armies
TEXT.Spanish: Professional Armies

TEXT.English: [TAB]By the early 14th century, the most effective armies were those consisting of professional, paid troops. At this point, these warriors were largely mercenaries, kings and magnates not yet being wealthy enough to maintain armies permanently. The ancient system of raising troops through feudal obligation had, in the meantime, fallen apart. This system, in its most common form, obligated each land holder to render 40 days of armed service a year to his overlord. In practice, the obligation also depended on how much land was held and the fine print in the original arrangement, Since the king was the "overlord of all overlords," he could, in theory, raise an enormous number of troops. In practice, the feudal armies were often quite ineffective. For one thing, the feudal obligation had an escape clause whereby the knights could pay money ("scutage") instead of showing up when called. Moreover, many knights promised to pay and somehow never got around to it. Even the troops that did show up were usually quite eager to go home as soon as the 40 day obligation was up, or even earlier if they could get away with it. Since a campaign generally lasted longer than 40 days, this time limit could prove very inconvenient for the leader of the feudal host. The English had, by this time, done away with the traditional feudal system and replaced it by one where the feudal lords were still obliged to supply troops, but they would be paid and would stay in service for as long as the king could meet the payroll. The French were moving towards a similar system, although they were not as well organized as the English, and would not be until the end of the war. [PARAGRAPH:2]Going into the 14th century, the idea of mercenary military service had caught on in a big way in Europe. Knights and commoners under arms were all eager to take the gold of anyone looking to raise an army. The table below shows the rates of pay that had become common during the period.

The French were moving towards a similar system, although they were not as well organized as the English, and would not be until the end of the war. [PARAGRAPH:2]Going into the 14th century, the idea of mercenary military service had caught on in a big way in Europe. Knights and commoners under arms were all eager to take the gold of anyone looking to raise an army. The table below shows the rates of pay that had become common during the period.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Zu Beginn des 14. Jahrhunderts bestanden die effektivsten Armeen aus professionellen, bezahlten Truppen. Zu diesem Zeitpunkt waren diese Krieger größtenteils Söldner, da Könige und Magnaten noch nicht reich genug waren, um ihre Armeen dauerhaft zu unterhalten. Das alte System der Truppenaufstellung durch feudale Verpflichtung war inzwischen zusammengebrochen. Dieses System verpflichtete in seiner gebräuchlichsten Form jeden Landbesitzer, seinem Oberherrn jährlich 40 Tage Militärdienst zu leisten. In der Praxis hing die Verpflichtung auch von der Landmenge und dem Kleingedruckten in der ursprünglichen Vereinbarung ab. Da der König der "Oberherr aller Oberherren" war, konnte er theoretisch eine enorme Anzahl an Truppen aufstellen. In der Praxis waren die feudalen Armeen oft recht wirkungslos. Zum einen enthielt die feudale Verpflichtung eine Ausweichklausel, die es den Rittern ermöglichte, Geld zu zahlen ("scutage"), anstatt zu erscheinen, wenn sie gerufen wurden. Darüber hinaus versprachen viele Ritter zu zahlen und kamen irgendwie nie dazu. Sogar die Truppen, die auftauchten, wollten normalerweise sofort nach Ablauf der 40-Tage-Pflicht nach Hause gehen, oder sogar früher, wenn sie damit durchkommen konnten. Da ein Feldzug in der Regel länger als 40 Tage dauerte, konnte sich diese Frist für den Anführer des Feudalheeres als sehr ungünstig erweisen. Zu diesem Zeitpunkt hatten die Engländer das traditionelle Feudalsystem abgeschafft und durch ein System ersetzt, bei dem die Feudalherren immer noch verpflichtet waren, Truppen bereitzustellen, diese jedoch bezahlt wurden und so lange im Dienst blieben, wie der König dies leisten konnte Lohn-und Gehaltsabrechnung. Die Franzosen waren auf dem Weg zu einem ähnlichen System, obwohl sie nicht so gut organisiert waren wie die Engländer und dies auch erst nach Kriegsende der Fall sein würde. [PARAGRAPH:2]Zu Beginn des 14. Jahrhunderts hatte die Idee des Söldner-Militärdienstes in Europa großen Anklang gefunden. Ritter und unter Waffen stehende Bürger waren alle begierig darauf, jedem, der eine Armee aufstellen wollte, das Gold abzunehmen. Die folgende Tabelle zeigt die in diesem Zeitraum üblichen Lohnsätze.

TEXT.English: Sanitation
TEXT.French: Sanitation
TEXT.German: Hygiene
TEXT.Italian: Sanitation
TEXT.Spanish: Sanitation

TEXT.English: [TAB]The increased waste produced by growing populations over time eventually led to potential health hazards. It then became necessary to come up with systems to dispose of garbage and human waste in a sanitary manner. Plumbing systems designed to remove wastewater from dwellings and public buildings became commonplace, as did sewage plants which treated the wastewater before it was dumped into local waterways. Landfills were established, and garbage was collected for sanitary disposal in dumps and landfills a safe distance from the general population. These measures led to a healthier environment, and allowed for further population growth.

Landfills were established, and garbage was collected for sanitary disposal in dumps and landfills a safe distance from the general population. These measures led to a healthier environment, and allowed for further population growth.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der zunehmende Abfall, der durch die wachsende Bevölkerung im Laufe der Zeit produziert wurde, führte schließlich zu potenziellen Gesundheitsrisiken. Dann wurde es notwendig, Systeme zu entwickeln, um Müll und menschliche Ausscheidungen auf hygienische Weise zu entsorgen. Sanitärsysteme zur Ableitung von Abwasser aus Wohnhäusern und öffentlichen Gebäuden waren ebenso üblich wie Kläranlagen, die das Abwasser aufbereiteten, bevor es in örtliche Gewässer eingeleitet wurde. Es wurden Mülldeponien eingerichtet und der Müll zur hygienischen Entsorgung auf Mülldeponien und Mülldeponien in sicherer Entfernung von der allgemeinen Bevölkerung gesammelt. Diese Maßnahmen führten zu einer gesünderen Umwelt und ermöglichten ein weiteres Bevölkerungswachstum.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Islamic architecture began in the 7th century, incorporating architectural forms from the ancient Middle East and Byzantium, but also developing features to suit the religious and social needs of the society. Examples can be found throughout the Middle East, Turkey, North Africa, the Indian Sub-continent and in parts of Europe, such as Spain, Albania, and the Balkan States, as the result of the expansion of the Ottoman Empire.

Beispiele finden sich im gesamten Nahen Osten, in der Türkei, in Nordafrika, auf dem indischen Subkontinent und in Teilen Europas wie Spanien, Albanien und den Balkanstaaten als Folge der Expansion des Osmanischen Reiches.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Flintlock is a general term for any firearm that uses a flint-striking ignition mechanism, the first of which appeared in Western Europe in the early 16th century. The term may also apply to a particular form of the mechanism itself, also known as the true flintlock, that was introduced in the early 17th century, and gradually replaced earlier firearm-ignition technologies, such as the matchlock, the wheellock, and the earlier flintlock mechanisms such as snaplock and snaphaunce. The true flintlock continued to be in common use for over two centuries, replaced by percussion cap and, later, the cartridge-based systems in the early-to-mid 19th century. Although long superseded by modern firearms, flintlock weapons enjoy continuing popularity with black-powder shooting enthusiasts.

The term may also apply to a particular form of the mechanism itself, also known as the true flintlock, that was introduced in the early 17th century, and gradually replaced earlier firearm-ignition technologies, such as the matchlock, the wheellock, and the earlier flintlock mechanisms such as snaplock and snaphaunce. The true flintlock continued to be in common use for over two centuries, replaced by percussion cap and, later, the cartridge-based systems in the early-to-mid 19th century. Although long superseded by modern firearms, flintlock weapons enjoy continuing popularity with black-powder shooting enthusiasts.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Steinschloss ist ein allgemeiner Begriff für jede Schusswaffe, die einen Feuerstein-Zündmechanismus verwendet, der erstmals im frühen 16. Jahrhundert in Westeuropa auftauchte. Der Begriff kann sich auch auf eine bestimmte Form des Mechanismus selbst beziehen, auch bekannt als echtes Steinschloss, das im frühen 17. Jahrhundert eingeführt wurde und nach und nach frühere Feuerwaffen-Zündtechnologien wie das Luntenschloss, das Radschloss und die früheren ersetzte Steinschlossmechanismen wie Snaplock und Snaphaunce. Das echte Steinschloss war noch über zwei Jahrhunderte lang gebräuchlich und wurde Anfang bis Mitte des 19. Jahrhunderts durch Perkussionskappen- und später durch Patronensysteme ersetzt. Obwohl moderne Feuerwaffen längst an ihre Stelle getreten sind, erfreuen sich Steinschlosswaffen bei Schwarzpulver-Schießfreunden nach wie vor großer Beliebtheit.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Matchlock was the first mechanism or "lock" invented to facilitate the firing of a hand-held firearm. It was invented in Europe some time in the mid 1400s, although the idea of the serpentine appears some 40 years previously in an Austrian manuscript. The first dated illustration of a matchlock mechanism dates to 1475, and by the 1500s they were universally used. [PARAGRAPH:2]A further development of flash pan technology, the classic European matchlock gun held a burning slow match in a clamp at the end of a small curved lever known as the serpentine. Upon pulling a second lever (or in later models a trigger) protruding from the bottom of the gun and connected to the serpentine, the clamp dropped down, lowering the burning match into the flash pan and igniting the priming powder. The flash from the primer travelled through the touch hole igniting the main charge of propellant in the gun barrel. This design removed the need to lower a lighted match into the flashpan by hand and made it possible to have both hands free to keep a firm grip on the weapon at the moment of firing, and to keep both eyes on the target. [PARAGRAPH:2]An inherent weakness of the matchlock was the necessity of keeping the match constantly lit. Being the sole source of ignition for the powder, if the match was not lit when the gun needed to be fired, the mechanism was useless, and the weapon became little more than an expensive club. This was chiefly a problem in wet weather, when damp match cord was difficult to light and to keep burning. Another drawback was the burning match itself. At night, the match would glow in the darkness, potentially giving away the carrier's position. The distinctive smell of burning match-cord was also a give away of a musketeer's position. It was also quite dangerous when a group of men were speedily handling large quantities of gunpowder along with lighted matches. This was one reason why soldiers in charge of transporting and guarding gunpowder were amongst the first to be issued self-igniting guns like the wheellock and snaphance.

Being the sole source of ignition for the powder, if the match was not lit when the gun needed to be fired, the mechanism was useless, and the weapon became little more than an expensive club. This was chiefly a problem in wet weather, when damp match cord was difficult to light and to keep burning. Another drawback was the burning match itself. At night, the match would glow in the darkness, potentially giving away the carrier's position. The distinctive smell of burning match-cord was also a give away of a musketeer's position. It was also quite dangerous when a group of men were speedily handling large quantities of gunpowder along with lighted matches. This was one reason why soldiers in charge of transporting and guarding gunpowder were amongst the first to be issued self-igniting guns like the wheellock and snaphance.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Das Luntenschloss war der erste Mechanismus oder "Schloss", der erfunden wurde, um das Abfeuern einer Handfeuerwaffe zu erleichtern. Sie wurde irgendwann in der Mitte des 15. Jahrhunderts in Europa erfunden, obwohl die Idee der Serpentine etwa 40 Jahre zuvor in einem österreichischen Manuskript auftauchte. Die erste datierte Abbildung eines Luntenschlossmechanismus stammt aus dem Jahr 1475 und im 16. Jahrhundert waren sie allgemein verbreitet. [PARAGRAPH:2]Eine Weiterentwicklung der Flash-Pan-Technologie: Die klassische europäische Luntenschlosspistole hielt ein brennendes, langsames Streichholz in einer Klemme am Ende eines kleinen gebogenen Hebels, der als Serpentine bekannt ist. Durch Ziehen eines zweiten Hebels (oder bei späteren Modellen eines Abzugs), der aus der Unterseite der Waffe herausragte und mit der Serpentine verbunden war, senkte sich die Klammer, senkte das brennende Streichholz in die Blitzpfanne und entzündete das Zündpulver. Der Blitz des Zündhütchens gelangte durch das Zündloch und zündete die Haupttreibstoffladung im Geschützrohr. Diese Konstruktion machte es überflüssig, ein brennendes Streichholz von Hand in die Blitzpfanne zu senken, und ermöglichte es, beide Hände frei zu haben, um die Waffe im Moment des Abfeuerns fest im Griff zu behalten und beide Augen auf das Ziel gerichtet zu halten. [PARAGRAPH:2]Eine inhärente Schwäche des Luntenschlosses war die Notwendigkeit, das Streichholz ständig brennen zu lassen. Da das Streichholz die einzige Zündquelle für das Pulver darstellte, war der Mechanismus nutzlos, wenn das Streichholz nicht angezündet wurde, als die Waffe abgefeuert werden musste, und die Waffe wurde kaum mehr als ein teurer Schläger. Dies war vor allem bei nassem Wetter ein Problem, wenn feuchte Streichholzschnur schwer anzuzünden und weiter zu brennen war. Ein weiterer Nachteil war das brennende Streichholz selbst. Nachts leuchtete das Streichholz in der Dunkelheit und verriet möglicherweise die Position des Trägers. Auch der charakteristische Geruch brennender Streichholzschnur verriet die Position eines Musketiers. Es war auch ziemlich gefährlich, wenn eine Gruppe von Männern schnell große Mengen Schießpulver und brennende Streichhölzer handhabte. Dies war einer der Gründe, warum Soldaten, die für den Transport und die Bewachung von Schießpulver zuständig waren, zu den ersten gehörten, denen selbstzündende Waffen wie die Radschloss- und die Snaphance-Waffen ausgehändigt wurden.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]The Matchlock was the first mechanism or "lock" invented to facilitate the firing of a hand-held firearm. It was invented in Europe some time in the mid 1400s, although the idea of the serpentine appears some 40 years previously in an Austrian manuscript. The first dated illustration of a matchlock mechanism dates to 1475, and by the 1500s they were universally used. [PARAGRAPH:2]A further development of flash pan technology, the classic European matchlock gun held a burning slow match in a clamp at the end of a small curved lever known as the serpentine. Upon pulling a second lever (or in later models a trigger) protruding from the bottom of the gun and connected to the serpentine, the clamp dropped down, lowering the burning match into the flash pan and igniting the priming powder. The flash from the primer travelled through the touch hole igniting the main charge of propellant in the gun barrel. This design removed the need to lower a lighted match into the flashpan by hand and made it possible to have both hands free to keep a firm grip on the weapon at the moment of firing, and to keep both eyes on the target. [PARAGRAPH:2]An inherent weakness of the matchlock was the necessity of keeping the match constantly lit. Being the sole source of ignition for the powder, if the match was not lit when the gun needed to be fired, the mechanism was useless, and the weapon became little more than an expensive club. This was chiefly a problem in wet weather, when damp match cord was difficult to light and to keep burning. Another drawback was the burning match itself. At night, the match would glow in the darkness, potentially giving away the carrier's position. The distinctive smell of burning match-cord was also a give away of a musketeer's position. It was also quite dangerous when a group of men were speedily handling large quantities of gunpowder along with lighted matches. This was one reason why soldiers in charge of transporting and guarding gunpowder were amongst the first to be issued self-igniting guns like the wheellock and snaphance.

TEXT.English: Wheellock
TEXT.French: Wheellock
TEXT.German: Radschloss
TEXT.Italian: Wheellock
TEXT.Spanish: Wheellock

TEXT.English: [TAB]A wheellock, wheel-lock, or wheel lock is a friction-wheel mechanism which creates a spark that causes a firearm to fire. It was the next major development in firearms technology after the matchlock and the first self-igniting firearm. Its name is from its rotating steel wheel to provide ignition. Developed in Europe around 1500, it was used alongside the matchlock and later the snaplock (1540s), the snaphance (1560s), and the flintlock (c. 1610s).
TEXT.French: [TAB]A wheellock, wheel-lock, or wheel lock is a friction-wheel mechanism which creates a spark that causes a firearm to fire. It was the next major development in firearms technology after the matchlock and the first self-igniting firearm. Its name is from its rotating steel wheel to provide ignition. Developed in Europe around 1500, it was used alongside the matchlock and later the snaplock (1540s), the snaphance (1560s), and the flintlock (c. 1610s).
TEXT.German: [TAB]Das Radschloss ist ein Reibradmechanismus, der einen Funken erzeugt, der den Schuss einer Schusswaffe auslöst. Es war die nächste große Entwicklung in der Schusswaffentechnologie nach dem Luntenschloss und der ersten selbstzündenden Schusswaffe. Seinen Namen verdankt es dem rotierenden Stahlrad, das für die Zündung sorgt. Es wurde um 1500 in Europa entwickelt und neben dem Luntenschloss und später dem Schnappschloss (1540er Jahre), dem Snaphance (1560er Jahre) und dem Steinschloss (ca. 1610er Jahre) verwendet.

TEXT.English: "It is He Who has set the stars for you, so that you may guide your course with their help through the darkness of the land and the sea." - Qur'an 6:97

TEXT.English: [TAB]In the early days of seafaring, sailors operated solely through a process known as "piloting", in which the position and course of the ship was determined by referring to geographical landmarks. The need to stay in view of the shore severely limited the extent of sea voyages. Through experience, sailors learned to apply the science of astronomy to their profession, noting the positions and movement of particular stars. They realized that even when the shore was out of sight, they could steer by certain reliable stars. This crude, yet practical application of astronomy allowed the adventurous to sail into the unknown with a reasonable chance of finding their way. As a result, ship building technology quickly improved, producing larger, more stable ships designed for longer voyages.

The need to stay in view of the shore severely limited the extent of sea voyages. Through experience, sailors learned to apply the science of astronomy to their profession, noting the positions and movement of particular stars. They realized that even when the shore was out of sight, they could steer by certain reliable stars. This crude, yet practical application of astronomy allowed the adventurous to sail into the unknown with a reasonable chance of finding their way. As a result, ship building technology quickly improved, producing larger, more stable ships designed for longer voyages.
TEXT.German: [TAB]In den Anfängen der Seefahrt operierten Seeleute ausschließlich durch einen Prozess namens "Lotsen", bei dem die Position und der Kurs des Schiffes anhand geografischer Orientierungspunkte bestimmt wurden. Die Notwendigkeit, im Blick auf die Küste zu bleiben, schränkte den Umfang der Seereisen stark ein. Durch Erfahrung lernten Seeleute, die Wissenschaft der Astronomie auf ihren Beruf anzuwenden und die Positionen und Bewegungen bestimmter Sterne zu notieren. Sie erkannten, dass sie sich auch dann an bestimmten zuverlässigen Sternen orientieren konnten, wenn das Ufer außer Sichtweite war. Diese grobe, aber praktische Anwendung der Astronomie ermöglichte es Abenteurern, ins Unbekannte zu segeln und dabei eine angemessene Chance zu haben, ihren Weg zu finden. Infolgedessen verbesserte sich die Schiffbautechnologie schnell und es entstanden größere, stabilere Schiffe, die für längere Reisen konzipiert waren.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Age of Discovery or Age of Exploration was a period from the early 15th century and continuing into the early 17th century, during which European ships traveled around the world to search for new trading routes and partners to feed burgeoning capitalism in Europe. They also were in search of trading goods such as gold, silver and spices. In the process, Europeans encountered peoples and mapped lands previously unknown to them. Among the most famous explorers of the period were Christopher Columbus, Vasco da Gama, Pedro Alvares Cabral, John Cabot, Yermak, Juan Ponce de Leon, Juan Sebastian Elcano, Bartholomew Dias, Ferdinand Magellan, Willem Barentsz, Abel Tasman, Jacques Cartier, Samuel de Champlain, Willem Jansz and Captain James Cook. [PARAGRAPH:2]The Age of Exploration was rooted in new technologies and ideas growing out of the Renaissance. These included advances in cartography, navigation, firepower and shipbuilding. Many people wanted to find a route to Asia through the west of Europe. The most important development was the invention of first the carrack and then caravel in Iberia. These vessels evolved from medieval European designs with a fruitful combination of Mediterranean and North Sea innovations and the addition of some Arabic elements. They were the first ships that could leave the relatively placid and calm Mediterranean and sail safely on the open Atlantic.

They also were in search of trading goods such as gold, silver and spices. In the process, Europeans encountered peoples and mapped lands previously unknown to them. Among the most famous explorers of the period were Christopher Columbus, Vasco da Gama, Pedro Alvares Cabral, John Cabot, Yermak, Juan Ponce de Leon, Juan Sebastian Elcano, Bartholomew Dias, Ferdinand Magellan, Willem Barentsz, Abel Tasman, Jacques Cartier, Samuel de Champlain, Willem Jansz and Captain James Cook. Many people wanted to find a route to Asia through the west of Europe. The most important development was the invention of first the carrack and then caravel in Iberia. These vessels evolved from medieval European designs with a fruitful combination of Mediterranean and North Sea innovations and the addition of some Arabic elements. They were the first ships that could leave the relatively placid and calm Mediterranean and sail safely on the open Atlantic.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Das Zeitalter der Entdeckungen oder Zeitalter der Erforschung war eine Zeit vom frühen 15. Jahrhundert bis ins frühe 17. Jahrhundert, in der europäische Schiffe um die Welt reisten, um nach neuen Handelsrouten und Partnern zu suchen, um den aufkeimenden Kapitalismus in Europa zu ernähren. Sie waren auch auf der Suche nach Handelsgütern wie Gold, Silber und Gewürzen. Dabei begegneten die Europäer Völkern und kartierten Länder, die ihnen zuvor unbekannt waren. Zu den berühmtesten Entdeckern dieser Zeit gehörten Christoph Kolumbus, Vasco da Gama, Pedro Alvares Cabral, John Cabot, Yermak, Juan Ponce de Leon, Juan Sebastian Elcano, Bartholomäus Dias, Ferdinand Magellan, Willem Barentsz, Abel Tasman, Jacques Cartier und Samuel de Champlain, Willem Jansz und Kapitän James Cook. [PARAGRAPH:2]Das Zeitalter der Entdeckungen hatte seine Wurzeln in neuen Technologien und Ideen, die aus der Renaissance hervorgingen. Dazu gehörten Fortschritte in der Kartographie, Navigation, Feuerkraft und im Schiffbau. Viele Menschen wollten einen Weg nach Asien durch den Westen Europas finden. Die wichtigste Entwicklung war die Erfindung zunächst der Karacke und dann der Karavelle in Iberien. Diese Schiffe entwickelten sich aus mittelalterlichen europäischen Designs mit einer fruchtbaren Kombination von Innovationen aus dem Mittelmeerraum und der Nordsee und der Hinzufügung einiger arabischer Elemente. Sie waren die ersten Schiffe, die das relativ ruhige Mittelmeer verlassen und sicher über den offenen Atlantik segeln konnten.

TEXT.English: Mercantilism
TEXT.French: Mercantilism
TEXT.German: Merkantilismus
TEXT.Italian: Mercantilism
TEXT.Spanish: Mercantilism

TEXT.English: [TAB]Mercantilism came into being shortly after the medieval states of Europe became true nation-states. It is an economic worldview holding that all economic exchange is zero-sum (meaning that in any trade, there is a winner and a loser). According to mercantilism national governments needed to tightly control foreign trade and employment, and aggressively pursue colonies and foreign markets to profitably sell manufactured goods. Finally, mercantilism was associated with the idea that wealth was identical with stocks of gold and silver, or whatever was used as currency in a given economy. Mercantilism endured until the 18th century, when Adam Smith and the classical liberals of England and France set forth a series of devastating criticisms.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Mercantilism came into being shortly after the medieval states of Europe became true nation-states. It is an economic worldview holding that all economic exchange is zero-sum (meaning that in any trade, there is a winner and a loser). According to mercantilism national governments needed to tightly control foreign trade and employment, and aggressively pursue colonies and foreign markets to profitably sell manufactured goods. Finally, mercantilism was associated with the idea that wealth was identical with stocks of gold and silver, or whatever was used as currency in a given economy. Mercantilism endured until the 18th century, when Adam Smith and the classical liberals of England and France set forth a series of devastating criticisms.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der Merkantilismus entstand kurz nachdem die mittelalterlichen Staaten Europas zu echten Nationalstaaten wurden. Es handelt sich um eine wirtschaftliche Weltanschauung, die davon ausgeht, dass der gesamte wirtschaftliche Austausch ein Nullsummenspiel ist (was bedeutet, dass es bei jedem Handel einen Gewinner und einen Verlierer gibt). Dem Merkantilismus zufolge mussten nationale Regierungen den Außenhandel und die Beschäftigung streng kontrollieren und Kolonien und ausländische Märkte aggressiv verfolgen, um Industriegüter gewinnbringend zu verkaufen. Schließlich wurde der Merkantilismus mit der Idee in Verbindung gebracht, dass Reichtum mit Gold- und Silberbeständen oder was auch immer in einer bestimmten Wirtschaft als Währung verwendet wird, identisch sei. Der Merkantilismus hielt bis ins 18. Jahrhundert an, als Adam Smith und die klassischen Liberalen Englands und Frankreichs eine Reihe vernichtender Kritiken vorbrachten.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Alchemy is both a philosophy and a practice with an aim of achieving ultimate wisdom as well as immortality, involving the improvement of the alchemist as well as the making of several substances described as possessing unusual properties.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Alchemy is both a philosophy and a practice with an aim of achieving ultimate wisdom as well as immortality, involving the improvement of the alchemist as well as the making of several substances described as possessing unusual properties.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Alchemie ist sowohl eine Philosophie als auch eine Praxis mit dem Ziel, höchste Weisheit und Unsterblichkeit zu erlangen. Dazu gehört die Verbesserung des Alchemisten sowie die Herstellung verschiedener Substanzen, die ungewöhnliche Eigenschaften besitzen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Alchemy is both a philosophy and a practice with an aim of achieving ultimate wisdom as well as immortality, involving the improvement of the alchemist as well as the making of several substances described as possessing unusual properties.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Alchemy is both a philosophy and a practice with an aim of achieving ultimate wisdom as well as immortality, involving the improvement of the alchemist as well as the making of several substances described as possessing unusual properties.

TEXT.English: "May I never see in the patient anything but a fellow creature in pain" - Oath of Maimonides
